Here is the expanded content:  "Avatar" is a 2009 science fiction film directed by James Cameron, set in the future on the planet Pandora, where a paraplegic marine named Jake Sully becomes an avatar of a native Na'vi warrior, leading to a clash between the human corporation and the native tribe over the mining of a valuable mineral.
In "Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End", the pirate lords gather in Singapore for a marriage ceremony between Elizabeth Swann and Will Turner, while the goddess Calypso is freed from her human form and seeks revenge against the pirates.
"Spectre" is the 24th film in the James Bond series, following the story of James Bond as he uncovers a sinister plot by the villainous Franz Oberhauser, who seeks to destroy the world using a powerful bomb, while also dealing with the emotional aftermath of the death of his love, Vesper Lynd.
The Dark Knight Rises is a 2012 superhero thriller film that concludes the The Dark Knight Trilogy, where Batman must face off against the villainous Bane, a ruthless terrorist who seeks to destroy Gotham City and its hero, while also dealing with the aftermath of the Joker's chaotic reign of terror.
John Carter, a 2012 science fiction film, is an adaptation of Edgar Rice Burroughs' novel "A Princess of Mars", which follows the story of John Carter, a former Confederate soldier who is transported to Mars, where he becomes embroiled in a conflict between the planet's various nations and falls in love with the princess Dejah Thoris.
Spider-Man 3, released in 2007, follows Peter Parker's struggles with the symbiote, which transforms him into the dark and aggressive Venom, while also introducing the villainous Sandman, who seeks revenge against Spider-Man.
Here is the expanded content:  "Tangled" is a 2010 American animated musical fantasy-comedy film loosely based on the German fairy tale "Rapunzel" by the Brothers Grimm, set in the 17th century and featuring a princess with magical hair that has the power to heal, who is locked away in a tower by a wicked witch and must be rescued by a charming thief named Flynn Rider.
Here is the expanded content:  Avengers: Age of Ultron is a 2015 superhero film directed by Joss Whedon, based on the Marvel Comics superhero team the Avengers, which follows the team as they face off against Ultron, an artificial intelligence created by Tony Stark and Bruce Banner that becomes self-aware and decides to destroy humanity, with the Avengers forced to band together to stop it and save the world.

The Lone Ranger is a 2013 American Western action comedy film directed by Gore Verbinski, starring Johnny Depp as Tonto, a Native American warrior, and Armie Hammer as John Reid, a Texas Ranger who becomes the titular Lone Ranger, as they team up to bring down the notorious outlaw Butch Cavendish and his gang.

The Avengers, a 2012 superhero film, follows Nick Fury, director of S.H.I.E.L.D., as he recruits Iron Man, Captain America, Thor, Hulk, Black Widow, and Hawkeye to form the Avengers team to stop an alien invasion led by Loki, who has stolen the Tesseract, a powerful energy source.

Schoedsack, about a giant ape named Kong who is discovered on a remote island and taken to New York City, where he escapes and wreaks havoc, abducting a beautiful woman named Ann Darrow, played by Fay Wray, in a iconic scene that has become a symbol of cinematic terror."

Sullivan, two monsters who attend Monsters University, a prestigious university for monsters, where they become rivals in a fraternity competition, but ultimately learn to put aside their differences and work together to overcome their cheating ways and achieve their goal of becoming the best scarers in the university."

Scott Fitzgerald, which tells the story of a man who is born with the physical appearance of an elderly man, but ages in reverse, and his unique experiences and relationships throughout his life.

Wells, which follows a scientist who travels through time to the year 802,701 and discovers a world vastly different from his own, where he falls in love with a woman from the future.

Amy Holden Jones is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for her work on the 1981 horror film "Munchies" and the 2018 thriller "The Slumber Party Massacre", as well as being a pioneer for women in the film industry.
"Analeine Cal y Mayor" is a 2009 Mexican drama film directed by Eugenio del Bosque, which tells the story of a young woman who returns to her hometown in the Yucatán Peninsula to care for her ailing mother and confront her own troubled past.
Anand Tucker is a British film director, known for his work on films such as "Hilary and Jackie" (1998), "Shopgirl" (2005), and "Transamerica" (2005), which earned Felicity Huffman an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress.
Andrea Arnold is a British film director, screenwriter, and producer known for her gritty and realistic portrayals of working-class life in films such as "Fish Tank", "Wuthering Heights", and "American Honey", which have garnered critical acclaim and numerous awards.
Andrea Di Stefano is an Italian film director, screenwriter, and actor, known for his work on films such as "The Great Beauty" and "Salt in the Wounds".
Andrei Tarkovsky was a renowned Russian filmmaker known for his visually stunning and philosophically profound films, such as "Andrei Rublev", "Solaris", and "Stalker", which explored themes of spirituality, identity, and the human condition.
Andrew Adamson is a New Zealand film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the Shrek franchise, The Chronicles of Narnia trilogy, and Mr. Popper's Penguins.
Andrew Bergman is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the comedy classics "The In-Laws" (1979), "Blazing Saddles" (1974), and "Honeymoon in Vegas" (1992).
Andrew Bujalski is an American independent film director, writer, and actor known for his unique, dialogue-driven style and his work on films such as "Funny Ha Ha", "Mutual Appreciation", and "Computer Chess".
Andrew Currie is a Canadian film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2007 zombie comedy film "Fido", which was based on a short film of the same name that he wrote and directed in 2006.
Andrew Davis is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing iconic films such as "The Package" (1989), "The Fugitive" (1993), and "The Guardian" (2006).
Andrew Dominik is a New Zealand-born Australian film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his critically acclaimed films such as "Chopper", "The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford", and "Killing Them Softly", which have garnered numerous awards and nominations, including several Academy Award nominations.
Andrew Douglas is a British film director, best known for directing the 2002 horror film "The Ring", a remake of the Japanese horror classic.
Andrew Erwin is a Christian film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing films such as "I Can Only Imagine" and "I Still Believe", which are based on the true stories of Christian musicians and have gained significant popularity among faith-based audiences.
Andrew Fleming is a Canadian film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on films such as "The Craft" (1996), "Thirteen Ghosts" (2001), and "Dick" (1999).

Andrew Jarecki is a documentary filmmaker known for directing the Academy Award-nominated films "Capturing the Friedmans" (2003) and "The Imposter" (2012), as well as the feature film "All Good Things" (2010), which was inspired by the true story of a real estate heir who was accused of murder.
Andrew Morahan is a British film and television director, best known for directing the 1991 film "Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves" starring Kevin Costner and Alan Rickman.
Andrew Niccol is a New Zealand-born screenwriter, producer, and film director known for his work on thought-provoking and visually stunning films such as "The Truman Show", "Gattaca", "Lord of War", and "In Time".
Andrew Stanton is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and animator, best known for his work on Pixar Animation Studios' films such as "Finding Nemo", "WALL-E", and "Toy Story", and has also directed live-action films like "John Carter" and "The Secret Life of Arrietty".
Andrew Steggall is a British film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his 2017 film "Forever, and Ever, and Forever", which premiered at the Berlin International Film Festival and received critical acclaim for its poignant portrayal of a family's struggles with grief and trauma.

(2003), "Herbie: Fully Loaded" (2005), and "Professor Marston and the Wonder Women" (2017), which explores the life of Wonder Woman's creator, William Moulton Marston, and his polyamorous relationship with his wife and mistress.

Brandon Landers is a fictional character and the main protagonist in the 2013 American thriller film "The Call", played by Halle Berry, who takes a desperate call from a kidnapped teenager and must use her skills to rescue her before it's too late.
Brandon Trost is a Canadian cinematographer and director, known for his work on films such as "The Scorpion King", "The Hangover", and "The Master", as well as music videos and television shows.
Breck Eisner is an American film director, best known for directing the horror movies "Sahara" (2005), "The Crazies" (2010), and "The Loft" (2014), as well as the fantasy adventure film "The Last Witch Hunter" (2015).
Brenda Chapman is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and animator, best known for being the first female director of an animated feature film, "The Prince of Egypt" (1998), for which she won an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.
Brendan Malloy is a film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2004 film "Point Break" and co-writing the 2014 film "Need for Speed".
Brenton Spencer is a Canadian film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1994 film "Screamers" and the 2001 film "The Highwayman".
Brett Leonard is a film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1992 science fiction film "The Lawnmower Man" and the 1995 film "Virtuosity", which starred Denzel Washington and Russell Crowe.
Brett Piper is a Canadian filmmaker and special effects artist, best known for his work on cult classic films such as "The Creeping Terror" (1964) and "The Deadly Spawn" (1983), as well as his contributions to the sci-fi and horror genres.
Brett Ratner is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the Rush Hour franchise, X-Men: The Last Stand, and the 2019 Queen biopic Bohemian Rhapsody, which won four Academy Awards.
Brian A. Miller is an American film and television director, known for his work on films such as "The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift" and "S.W.A.T.: Under Siege", as well as TV shows like "Teen Wolf" and "Rizzoli & Isles".
Brian Baugh is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2016 film "Priceless" and the 2019 film "I Still Believe", a biographical romantic drama based on the life of Christian music star Jeremy Camp.
Brian Caunter is a British actor, best known for his role as Harvey Moon in the BBC sitcom "Moon and Son" and later as Eddie Roberts in the ITV soap opera "Family Affairs".
Brian Dannelly is an American film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2005 comedy-drama film "Saved!" which explores themes of teenage pregnancy, faith, and social hierarchy in a high school setting.
Brian De Palma is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his work on iconic films such as "Carrie", "Dressed to Kill", "Scarface", and "Mission: Impossible", often incorporating elements of suspense, thriller, and horror genres.
Brian Gibson is a British film director, best known for directing the 1991 film "The Commitments", a musical comedy-drama about a group of young working-class musicians in Dublin, Ireland.
Brian Helgeland is a renowned American screenwriter, film director, and producer, known for his work on iconic films such as "L.A. Confidential", "Mystic River", and "42", earning him numerous awards and nominations, including an Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay.
Brian Henson is a renowned British film director, producer, and puppeteer, best known for his work on the Muppets franchise, including directing the films "The Great Muppet Caper" (1981), "The Muppets Take Manhattan" (1984), and "Muppet Christmas Carol" (1992), as well as being the son of Muppets creator Jim Henson.
Brian Klugman is an American actor, writer, and director, best known for co-writing and starring in the 2011 film "The Proposal" alongside Sandra Bullock and Ryan Reynolds, and for his work on the TV series "Grey's Anatomy" and "The New Normal".
Brian Koppelman is a screenwriter, director, and producer, best known for co-writing the screenplay for the 1999 film "Rounders" with David Levien, and also for creating and producing the TV series "Billions" alongside David Levien and Andrew Ross Sorkin.
Brian Levant is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on family-friendly comedies such as "Beethoven", "The Flintstones", and "Garfield: The Movie".
Brian Percival is a British film and television director, best known for directing the first two films in the Harry Potter franchise, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" (2001) and "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" (2002), as well as the PBS Masterpiece drama series "Downton Abbey" (2010-2015).
Brian Robbins is a American film and television director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing films such as "Varsity Blues", "Ready to Rumble", and "The Perfect Score", as well as creating and producing popular TV shows like "Smallville" and "One Tree Hill".
Brian Trenchard-Smith is a Australian film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his work on cult classic films such as "Turkey Shoot", "BMX Bandits", and "Dead End Drive-In", and is often referred to as the "Master of Ozploitation" for his contributions to the Australian exploitation film genre.
Britt Allcroft is a British television producer and writer, best known for creating the popular children's television series "Thomas the Tank Engine & Friends" and "Shining Time Station", which were based on the Railway Series books by Reverend W. Awdry.
Bronwen Hughes is a New Zealand-born Canadian film and television director, best known for directing the 1997 film "She's All That" and the 2004 film "Stander", as well as episodes of popular TV shows such as "The Shield" and "The Walking Dead".
Bruce Beresford is a renowned Australian film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing iconic films such as "Breaker Morant", "Tender Mercies", and "Driving Miss Daisy", which won the Academy Award for Best Picture in 1989.

Bruce Paltrow was an American film and television director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the iconic 1980s film "Brideshead Revisited" and the popular television series "The White Shadow" and "St. Elsewhere".

Carl Theodor Dreyer was a Danish film director known for his highly influential and avant-garde films, including "The Passion of Joan of Arc" (1928), "Vampyr" (1932), and "Day of Wrath" (1943), which are considered some of the greatest films of all time.
Carlos Carrera is a Mexican film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his work on films such as "Backyard" (1984), "Matando Cabos" (2009), and "The Crime of Father Amaro" (2002), which won the Golden Lion at the 2002 Venice Film Festival.

Carlos Saura is a renowned Spanish film director, known for his work in the genres of drama, comedy, and documentary, and is particularly famous for his flamenco-themed films, such as "Blood Wedding" and "Carmen", which have won numerous awards and critical acclaim.
Carmen Marron is a 2002 American drama film directed by Richard A. Colla, starring Carmen Marron, who also wrote the screenplay, and tells the story of a young woman's journey to self-discovery and redemption after being released from prison.
Carol Reed was a renowned Irish-British film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing iconic films such as "The Third Man", "The Fallen Idol", "Oliver!", and "The Man Who Would Be King", among many others.
Caroline Link is a German film director and screenwriter, best known for her Academy Award-winning film "Nowhere in Africa" (2001), a biographical drama based on the true story of a Jewish family's escape from Nazi Germany.

Catherine Jelski is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 2014 psychological thriller film "Gone Girl", played by actress Rosamund Pike, who is a missing woman whose husband is suspected of her murder.
Cathy Malkasian is an American cartoonist and filmmaker, best known for creating the critically acclaimed animated film "The Trap Door" and the graphic novel series "Echo Chamber", which explores themes of existentialism, morality, and the human condition.
Cecil B. DeMille was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter who is best known for directing epic films such as "The Ten Commandments" and "Samson and Delilah", and is considered one of the most influential and successful filmmakers of the silent era and early talkies.
Cedric Nicolas-Troyan is a French visual effects artist and film director, best known for his work on the visual effects of the Twilight Saga film series and his directorial debut, The Huntsman: Winter's War.

Charlie Levine is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 2013 film "Ender's Game", based on the novel of the same name by Orson Scott Card, where he is a young boy who is recruited to attend a prestigious military academy to train as a commander in a future war.
Chatrichalerm Yukol is a Thai film director and producer, known for his work on films such as "Dung Fai La" (1999), "Ngo Jah" (2000), and "Sud Si Jai" (2002), which are considered some of the most iconic and influential Thai films of the 1990s and early 2000s.

Craig Bolotin is a Canadian screenwriter and producer, best known for his work on the 1994 film "Speed" starring Keanu Reeves and Sandra Bullock.

Craig Gillespie is a Australian film and television director, known for his work on films such as "Lars and the Real Girl", "Fright Night", and "I Tonya", as well as TV shows like "The United States of Tara" and "The Good Wife".
Craig Johnson is a writer and director known for creating the Walt Longmire mystery series, which was adapted into the popular TV show "Longmire" starring Robert Taylor, and is also the author of several novels featuring the same character.
Craig Mazin is a renowned American screenwriter, producer, and director, best known for his work on the HBO miniseries "Chernobyl" and "Wolves of Wall Street", as well as the comedy films "Scary Movie" and "The Hangover Part II".
Craig Moss is a film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the horror comedy films "Date Movie" (2006), "Epic Movie" (2007), and "Disaster Movie" (2008), which were all released by Lionsgate and received mixed reviews from critics.
Craig R. Baxley is a American film director, stuntman, and second unit director, known for his work on films such as "Aliens", "The Dark Half", and "Nash Bridges", as well as his collaborations with directors like James Cameron and John Carpenter.
Craig Zobel is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his work on films such as "Great World of Sound", "Compliance", and "Z for Zachariah", which have received critical acclaim for their thought-provoking and often uncomfortable explorations of human behavior.
Cristian Mungiu is a Romanian film director and screenwriter, best known for his critically acclaimed films such as "4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days" and "Beyond the Hills", which have won numerous awards and have been recognized for their thought-provoking and nuanced portrayals of Romanian society and culture.
Curtis Hanson is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his work on critically acclaimed films such as "L.A. Confidential", "8 Mile", and "In Her Shoes", among others.
Cyrus Nowrasteh is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the films "The Stoning of Soraya M." (2008), "The War Within" (2005), and "Hidalgo" (2004), as well as producing and writing for various television shows.
Cédric Klapisch is a French film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his poignant and humorous portrayals of everyday life in France, as seen in films like "Chocolat" and the "L'Auberge Espagnole" series.
Dennis Stevens, also known as D. Stevens, is a character from the 1994 film "Speed" played by Keanu Reeves, who is a Los Angeles Police Department SWAT team officer tasked with rescuing civilians from a bomb-laden city bus.
D.J. Caruso is a film director known for his work on movies such as "The Salton Sea", "Taking Lives", "Eagle Eye", and "I Am Number Four", often exploring themes of psychological suspense and thriller genres.
D.W. Griffith was a pioneering American film director, producer, and screenwriter who is best known for directing the groundbreaking and influential films "The Birth of a Nation" (1915) and "Intolerance" (1916), which showcased his innovative storytelling and cinematography techniques.
DJ Pooh is a fictional character and the main protagonist in the animated film "The Santa Clause" series, played by actor Eric Lloyd, who is the son of Scott Calvin, aka Santa Claus.
Dagur Kári is an Icelandic film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the animated films "Sorrow Me Not" and "The Good Heart", as well as the live-action films "I Believe in You" and "The Rebels".
Daisy von Scherler Mayer is a German-American film director, known for her work on films such as "Party Girl" (1995), "The Brothers McMullen" (1995), and "It's a Very Merry Muppet Christmas Movie" (2002).
Damien Chazelle is a critically acclaimed American film director, screenwriter, and composer known for his work on films such as "Whiplash", "La La Land", and "First Man", which have earned him numerous awards and nominations, including eight Academy Award nominations and three wins.
Damien Dante Wayans is an American actor, writer, and director, best known for being a member of the Wayans family, a prominent African-American family in the entertainment industry, and for his work on films and TV shows such as "Scary Movie" and "Dance Flick".
Damien O'Donnell is an Irish film and television director, known for his work on films such as "Calvary" and "Wild Mountain Thyme", as well as TV shows like "Peaky Blinders" and "The Fall".
Damon Santostefano is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the films "The Craft" (1996), "I Know What You Did Last Summer" (1997), and "Drive Me Crazy" (1999).
Dan Fogelman is a American screenwriter, director, and producer known for creating and writing the hit TV series "This Is Us" and directing films like "Crazy, Stupid, Love" and "Trolls".
Dan Gilroy is a American film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his work on films such as "Nightcrawler" (2014), "Roman J. Israel, Esq." (2017), and "Velvet Buzzsaw" (2019), which often explore themes of morality, technology, and the human condition.
Dan Harris is an American television journalist and anchor who is best known for his work as a co-anchor of ABC's Good Morning America Weekend Edition and as a correspondent for ABC News, and has also written a book titled "10% Happier: How I Tamed the Voice in My Head, Reduced Stress Without Losing My Edge, and Found a New Kind of Happiness" that explores his journey from being a skeptic to embracing meditation and mindfulness.
Dan Ireland was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1991 film "Singles" starring Bridget Fonda and Campbell Scott, as well as other notable films such as "The Whole Wide World" and "The Grey Zone".
Dan Mazer is a British comedy writer, director, and producer, best known for his work on the Borat and Bruno films, as well as the TV series Da Ali G Show and Episodes.
Dan O'Bannon was a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and special effects artist, best known for co-writing and producing the sci-fi horror classic "Alien" (1979) and co-creating the "Alien" franchise.
Dan Perri is a renowned American film editor, best known for his work on iconic films such as "Raiders of the Lost Ark" (1981), "Blade Runner" (1982), and "Apocalypse Now" (1979), earning him an Academy Award nomination for Best Film Editing.
Dan Rush is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the films "Everything Must Go" (2010) and "Kill the Messenger" (2014).
Dan Scanlon is an American film director, animator, and screenwriter, best known for directing the Pixar animated films "Monsters University" (2013) and "Onward" (2020).
Dan Trachtenberg is a film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2016 film "10 Cloverfield Lane", a psychological thriller that received critical acclaim and was a commercial success.
Dan Zukovic is a filmmaker and writer, best known for his critically acclaimed 1998 film "Hollywood Monster", a dark comedy about a struggling filmmaker who becomes obsessed with a mysterious and elusive film critic, and his 2013 film "Dreams of the Stargazer", a surreal and atmospheric drama that explores the themes of creativity, identity, and the human condition.
Daniel Algrant is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on films such as "Mistress" (1992), "The Twice and the Rest" (1994), "Falling Angels" (2003), and "Experimenter" (2015).
Daniel Barber is a British film director, known for his work on films such as "Harry Brown" (2009) and "Hickock" (2012), which showcased his ability to craft intense and emotionally charged dramas.
Daniel Barnz is a film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his work on films such as "Phoebe in Wonderland", "Beastly", and "Pretty Persuasion".
Daniel Columbie is a New Zealand film producer and director, best known for his work on the 2016 film "Hunt for the Wilderpeople" and the 2019 film "Jojo Rabbit", which won the Academy Award for Best Picture.
Daniel Davila is a Mexican film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2018 film "The Golden Dream" (La Sombra del Alebrije), which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival.
Daniel Espinosa is a Swedish film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the action-thriller film "Safe House" (2012) starring Denzel Washington and Ryan Reynolds, as well as the sci-fi film "Life" (2017) starring Jake Gyllenhaal and Rebecca Ferguson.
Daniel Hsia is a Taiwanese-American filmmaker and writer, best known for his work on the Netflix series "American Vandal" and the feature film "Saving Face", which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival in 2004.
Daniel Lee is a Hong Kong film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "The Bridge with Dragon" (1985), "The Twins Effect" (2003), and "Flash Point" (2007), which have gained him recognition in the action and martial arts film genres.
Daniel Mellitz is a German film editor, best known for his work on films such as "Barbara" and "Phoenix", which have received critical acclaim for their nuanced and atmospheric storytelling.
Daniel Petrie Jr. is a renowned American screenwriter and producer, best known for his work on films such as Beverly Hills Cop, Coming to America, and Made in America, and has received multiple award nominations for his contributions to the film industry.
Daniel Sackheim is an American television director and producer, known for his work on popular TV shows such as "The Walking Dead", "The Americans", and "Better Call Saul", as well as directing episodes of "Game of Thrones" and "The Handmaid's Tale".
Daniel Schechter is a French-American film director, screenwriter, and editor, best known for his work on the animated films "Louise by the Shore" and "The Big Bad Fox and Other Tales", as well as his collaborations with directors such as Wes Anderson and Olivier Nakache.
Daniel Stamm is a German film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the horror films "A Dark Song" (2016) and "The Last Exorcism" (2010), which received critical acclaim and commercial success.
Daniel Taplitz is an American screenwriter and playwright, best known for writing the 1992 film "Passion Fish", which earned him an Academy Award nomination for Best Original Screenplay.

Danny Provenzano is a fictional character and the main antagonist in the 1995 film "Get Shorty", played by Dennis Farina, who is a ruthless and cunning loan shark seeking revenge against John Travolta's character, Chili Palmer.
Dany Boon is a French actor, director, and writer, best known for his comedies such as "The Closet" and "Joyeux Noël", which often explore themes of identity, community, and the human condition.
Darin Scott is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1995 horror film "Screamers" and the 1997 thriller film "Exit to Panic".

Dave Rodriguez is a fictional character and the main protagonist in the 1993 American comedy film "Dave" starring Kevin Kline, where he is a lookalike of the President of the United States who is tasked with impersonating the President for a day.
David Anspaugh is an American film and television director, best known for directing the 1986 film "Hoosiers", a biographical sports drama based on the true story of the 1954 Indiana state basketball championship won by the small-town Milan High School team.
David Atkins is a Australian film and television writer, best known for creating the popular Australian television series "SeaChange" and "All Saints".

David Carson is a renowned American graphic designer and art director, best known for his work on the iconic 1990s MTV logo and his influence on the development of grunge and alternative design styles.

David Nixon was a British magician and television presenter who hosted the popular BBC television series "David Nixon's Magic Box" from 1958 to 1968, showcasing his own magic tricks and illusions as well as those of other magicians.

Don Scardino is an American television director, producer, and actor, best known for his work on the TV shows "30 Rock", "The Good Wife", and "Brooklyn Nine-Nine", as well as directing several episodes of popular TV series such as "The Sopranos", "Law & Order", and "Madam Secretary".
Don Siegel was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his work on iconic films such as "Dirty Harry", "The Shootist", and "Escape from Alcatraz", and was often referred to as "Jeebies" by Clint Eastwood, his frequent collaborator.
Don Taylor was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter who directed over 30 films, including "The Devil's Backbone", "Tora! Tora! Tora!", and "Bottle Rocket", and was also known for his work on television, including directing episodes of "The Twilight Zone" and "The Outer Limits".
Donald Petrie is a film director known for directing several romantic comedies, including "Mystic Pizza", "Grumpy Old Men", "The House Sitter", "Opportunity Knocks", "My Father the Hero", "While You Were Sleeping", and "How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days".
Doug Atchison is a film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2002 film "Coach Carter", a biographical sports drama starring Samuel L. Jackson.
Doug Lefler is an American film editor, best known for his work on the 2003 film "Hulk" and the 2006 film "Smokin' Aces".
Doug Liman is a film director known for his work on movies such as "Swingers", "Go", "Mr. & Mrs. Smith", "The Bourne Identity", "Mr. Brooks", "Jumper", "Fair Game", "Edge of Tomorrow", and "American Made".
Douglas Aarniokoski is a Finnish-American film director and cinematographer, known for his work on films such as "The Day the Earth Stood Still" (2008), "The Rite" (2011), and "Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1" (2014).
Douglas McGrath is an American screenwriter, director, and actor, best known for writing and directing the films "Bulworth" (1998), "Emma" (1996), and "Nicholas Nickleby" (2002), as well as co-writing the screenplay for "Bullets Over Broadway" (1994), which earned him an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.
Douglas Trumbull is a renowned American visual effects artist and film director, best known for his work on iconic films such as "2001: A Space Odyssey", "Close Encounters of the Third Kind", and "Blade Runner", earning him multiple Academy Award nominations and a reputation as a master of cinematic visual effects.
Drake Doremus is a American film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his work on films such as "Like Crazy", "Breathe In", and "The Fault in Our Stars".
Drew Barrymore is a renowned American actress, producer, and director who has appeared in a wide range of films, including "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial", "Scream", "Charlie's Angels", and "50 First Dates", and has been recognized with numerous awards and nominations throughout her career.
"Duane Journey" is likely a reference to the 1985 film "Back to the Future" by Robert Zemeckis, where the main character Marty McFly's friend Duane is mentioned, and the film's protagonist Marty travels back in time to November 5, 1955, to ensure that his parents, George and Lorraine, fall in love and marry, thereby securing his own existence.
Duke Johnson is a stop-motion animation director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "The Fantastic Flying Books of Mr. Morris Lessmore" and "Anomalisa", which received critical acclaim and numerous awards, including the Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film.
Duncan Jones is a British film director and producer, best known for directing the science fiction films "Moon" (2009), "Source Code" (2011), and "Warcraft" (2016), and is the son of David Bowie.
Duncan Tucker is an American film director, best known for his work on the 2005 film "Transamerica", a critically acclaimed drama starring Felicity Huffman as a pre-operative trans woman, which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival and received several Academy Award nominations.
Dustin Hoffman is a renowned American actor known for his iconic roles in films such as "The Graduate", "Midnight Cowboy", "Tootsie", and "Rain Man", among many others, earning him numerous awards and nominations throughout his illustrious career.
Dwight H. Little is a film director, known for directing horror movies such as "Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers" (1988), "The Gate" (1987), and "Free Willy" (1993).
E. Elias Merhige is an American filmmaker and artist, best known for directing the experimental film "Shadow of the Vampire" (2000), which was inspired by the making of the 1922 German silent film "Nosferatu".
E.L. Katz is a film director and screenwriter known for his work on horror and thriller films, including the critically acclaimed "Cheap Thrills" (2013) and "Small Crimes" (2017).
Ed Decter is a renowned American film and television writer, producer, and director, best known for his work on popular TV shows such as "Roseanne", "The Larry Sanders Show", and "Entourage", as well as films like "There's Something About Mary" and "Wild Hogs".
Ed Gass-Donnelly is a Canadian film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his work on films such as "This Beautiful City" and "Small Engine Repair".
Ed Harris is a renowned American actor, known for his versatility and range, having appeared in a wide variety of films, including "Apollo 13", "The Truman Show", "A History of Violence", and "Westworld", among many others.
Eddie O'Flaherty was a fictional character in the 1997 film "The Ice Storm" directed by Ang Lee, played by Elijah Wood, who is a troubled teenager struggling with his family's dysfunctional relationships during the 1970s.
Edgar Wright is a British film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his unique visual style and genre-bending films such as Shaun of the Dead, Hot Fuzz, and Scott Pilgrim vs. the World, which have gained a cult following and critical acclaim.
Edward Burns is an American actor, writer, and director, known for his work on films such as "The Brothers McMullen", "She's the One", and "Saving Private Ryan", and has also appeared in numerous other films and television shows.
Edward Hall was a British film director, best known for directing the 1979 horror film "The Evil Dead" and its 1987 sequel "Evil Dead II", which have since become cult classics.
Edward Norton is a renowned American actor known for his versatility and range, having appeared in a wide variety of films such as "American History X", "Fight Club", "The Illusionist", and "Birdman", among many others.
Edward Zwick is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for directing iconic films such as "Glory", "Legends of the Fall", "The Last Samurai", and "Blood Diamond", among many others.
Efram Potelle is an American film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2004 teen comedy film "But I'm a Cheerleader" and the 2011 drama film "Moon".
Ekachai Uekrongtham is a Thai film director and screenwriter, known for his work on films such as "The Beauty Business" and "Sex Aphrodite", which often explore themes of sexuality, identity, and social issues in Thai society.
Elaine May is a renowned American comedian, actress, writer, and director, best known for her work as a member of the improvisational comedy duo The Second City, as well as her successful film career, including directing and starring in the 1970 comedy film "A New Leaf" and co-writing and starring in the 1978 comedy film "Heaven Can Wait".
Eldar Rapaport is a Russian-born American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the 2004 film "The Terminal" starring Tom Hanks and Catherine Zeta-Jones.
Eli Craig is a Canadian film director, best known for directing the horror comedy film "Tucker & Dale vs Evil" (2010) and the horror film "Tragedy Girls" (2017).
Elia Kazan was a renowned Turkish-American film and theater director, producer, and actor who is best known for his work on films such as "On the Waterfront" and "East of Eden", as well as his influential direction of the Actors Studio, which helped launch the careers of Marlon Brando, James Dean, and Montgomery Clift.
Elizabeth Allen Rosenbaum is an American film director and screenwriter, known for directing films such as "The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants" (2005), "The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2" (2008), and "Beautiful Creatures" (2013).
Elizabeth Banks is an American actress, director, and producer, known for her roles in films such as "The Hunger Games" series, "Pitch Perfect 2", and "Power Rangers", as well as her work on TV shows like "Scrubs" and "30 Rock".
Ellory Elkayem is a New Zealand film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1999 horror film "Carnival of Souls", a remake of the 1962 cult classic of the same name.
Emilio Estevez is a renowned American actor, director, and writer, best known for his roles in iconic 1980s and 1990s films such as "The Breakfast Club", "St. Elmo's Fire", "Young Guns", and "The Mighty Ducks" series.
Emily Dell is a YouTube personality and filmmaker known for creating popular movie-themed challenges and parodies, such as "Movie Roulette" and "Movie Mashups", which have gained her a large following online.
Emily Young is a fictional character from the 1992 film "A River Runs Through It" played by Brad Pitt's real-life wife, Academy Award-winning actress Angelina Jolie.
Emma-Kate Croghan is an Australian film director and producer, best known for her work on the 1994 film "Muriel's Wedding", which won several awards at the Australian Film Institute Awards and was also nominated for the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.
Enrique Begne is a Spanish film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2019 film "Pain and Glory", which won the Best Director award at the 76th Golden Globe Awards and was nominated for three Academy Awards.
Eric Blakeney is a Canadian actor, best known for his role as Richard Malone in the 1990s TV series "Wiseguy".
Eric Brevig is a visual effects supervisor and director, best known for his work on films such as "Jumanji" (1995), "Pearl Harbor" (2001), and "Journey to the Center of the Earth" (2008), and has also directed the 2009 film "Yogi Bear".
Eric Bross is an American film director, writer, and producer, best known for directing the 1997 comedy film "Drive Me Crazy" starring Melissa Joan Hart and Adrian Grenier.
Eric Bugbee is a cinematographer and camera operator who has worked on several notable films, including "The Revenant" and "The Ballad of Buster Scruggs", and is known for his expertise in capturing stunning natural light and using innovative camera techniques to tell stories.
Eric Darnell is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and animator, best known for co-directing the Madagascar film franchise with Tom McGrath, as well as directing the animated films Antz and Madagascar 3: Europe's Most Wanted.
Eric Eason is an American screenwriter and film director, best known for writing the screenplay for the 2002 film "Manhood" and directing the 2011 film "Manito".
Eric England is a horror film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "Madhouse", "Contracted", and "Beneath", which have gained a cult following among horror fans for their intense and often disturbing depictions of violence and gore.
Eric Lartigau is a French film director, known for directing the 2011 comedy film "Little White Lies" and the 2016 drama film "The Bélier Family", which won several César Awards.

Eric Nicholas is a fictional character from the 2001 film "Not Another Teen Movie", played by actor Chyler Leigh, who is a popular high school student and the object of affection for the main character Jake Wyler.
Eric Schaeffer is an American actor, writer, and director, best known for creating and starring in the 1996 film "If Lucy Fell" and the 1999 film "My Life's a Film", as well as his work on the TV series "Relativity".

Eytan Fox is an Israeli film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his work on films such as "Yossi & Jagger" and "Walk on Water", which often explore themes of love, identity, and social issues in Israeli society.

Fabián Bielinsky is an Argentine film director and screenwriter, best known for his critically acclaimed films "Nine Queens" (2000) and "The Aura" (2005), which have gained international recognition for their unique storytelling and atmospheric direction.
Fatih Akin is a German-Turkish film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his critically acclaimed films such as "Head-On", "Crossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul", and "The Edge of Heaven", which often explore themes of identity, culture, and social issues within the Turkish-German community.

Fenton Bailey is a British film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on documentary films and television series, including "The Eyes of Tammy Faye" and "Party Monster".
Fernando Báez Mella is a 2022 Argentine drama film directed by Mariano De Rosa and Federico Epstein, based on the true story of a 17-year-old who brutally murdered a 16-year-old girl in a small town in Argentina in 1955.
Fernando León de Aranoa is a Spanish film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his critically acclaimed films such as "Barrio" (1998), "And Your Mother Too" (2001), and "A Perfect Day" (2015), which have garnered numerous awards and nominations at international film festivals.
Fernando Meirelles is a Brazilian film director, known for his work on films such as "City of God", "Blindness", and "360", which often explore themes of social inequality, poverty, and human relationships.
Feroz Abbas Khan is a renowned Indian film director, screenwriter, and playwright, known for his work on critically acclaimed films such as "Dor" and "Lakshya", and has also directed several successful plays and television shows.

Fina Torres is a Venezuelan film director and screenwriter, known for her work on films such as "Sangre de mi sangre" (1980), "Sólo con tu amor" (1987), and "La bella y la bestia" (1991), which have explored themes of love, family, and social issues in Venezuela.

Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck is a German film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his critically acclaimed films such as "The Lives of Others" (2006), "The Tourist" (2010), and "Never Look Away" (2018), which have garnered numerous awards and nominations, including the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film.
Floyd Mutrux is a film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his work on films such as "American Hot Wax" (1978), "Can't Stop the Music" (1980), and "Urban Cowboy" (1980), which was a critical and commercial success and helped launch the careers of its stars, including John Travolta and Debra Winger.

Francesca Gregorini is a British-Italian film director and screenwriter, best known for her work on the 2011 film "Trampoline", a psychological thriller starring Joaquin Phoenix and Jonah Hill.

Franco Zeffirelli was a renowned Italian film and opera director, best known for his iconic adaptations of Shakespearean plays, including "Romeo and Juliet" (1968) and "Hamlet" (1990), as well as his work on films such as "The Taming of the Shrew" (1967) and "Brother Sun, Sister Moon" (1972).

Frank Capra was a renowned American film director, producer, and writer, best known for directing iconic films such as "It's a Wonderful Life", "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington", and "Arsenic and Old Lace", earning him five Academy Awards and cementing his status as one of the most beloved and respected filmmakers of Hollywood's Golden Age.
Frank Coraci is a renowned American film director, best known for directing the hit movies "The Waterboy" (1998), "My Dog Skip" (2000), "Anger Management" (2003), and "Click" (2006), showcasing his versatility in handling a range of genres from comedy to drama.
Frank Darabont is a Hungarian-American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on horror and drama films, including the adaptations of Stephen King's novels "The Shawshank Redemption", "The Green Mile", and "The Mist".
Frank Lotito is an Australian actor, best known for his roles in the films "The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert" (1994) and "Muriel's Wedding" (1994), both of which were critically acclaimed and gained international recognition.

Frank Miller is a renowned comic book writer, novelist, and filmmaker, best known for his dark and gritty reimaginings of iconic characters such as Batman in "The Dark Knight Returns" and "Sin City", as well as directing the film adaptations of his own work, including "Sin City" and "300".
Frank Oz is a renowned puppeteer, director, and voice actor, best known for his work on the Muppets, including Miss Piggy, Fozzie Bear, and Sam the Eagle, as well as his direction of several Star Wars films, including "The Empire Strikes Back" and "Return of the Jedi".

François Truffaut was a French film director, screenwriter, and film critic who was a leading figure in the French New Wave movement, known for his iconic films such as "The 400 Blows", "Jules and Jim", and "Day for Night".

Fritz Lang was an Austrian-German-American film director, producer, and screenwriter who is considered one of the most influential filmmakers of the 20th century, known for his pioneering work in the development of science fiction, film noir, and the thriller genres, and directing iconic films such as "Metropolis", "M", and "The Big Heat".
Frédéric Auburtin is a French film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2004 film "Paris, je t'aime", a romantic comedy anthology film consisting of 18 short films set in Paris, each directed by a different filmmaker.
Frédéric Forestier is a French film director and screenwriter, best known for co-directing the 2001 film "Amélie" with Jean-Pierre Jeunet, which became a critical and commercial success and is often referred to as one of the most iconic and influential French films of the 21st century.

Georg Wilhelm Pabst was an Austrian film director, screenwriter, and producer who was known for his socially conscious and often provocative films, such as "Pandora's Box" (1929) and "Westfront 1918" (1930), which explored themes of morality, class, and the human condition.
George A. Romero was a renowned American filmmaker, best known for his influential and iconic zombie films, particularly the "Dead" series, which includes "Night of the Living Dead" (1968), "Dawn of the Dead" (1978), and "Day of the Dead" (1985), among others.
George Armitage is a film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1980 cult classic "Eddie Macon's Run" and the 1987 action film "Miller's Crossing", which was written by the Coen brothers.
George Clooney is a renowned American actor, director, and producer who has appeared in a wide range of films, including "ER", "Ocean's Eleven", "Syriana", "Gravity", and "The Descendants", among many others, and has received numerous awards and nominations for his work.
George Cukor was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter who directed over 80 films, including "Little Women", "The Philadelphia Story", and "My Fair Lady", and was known for his ability to elicit strong performances from his actors.
George Gallo is a American screenwriter, director, and producer, best known for writing the screenplay for the 1995 film "Bad Boys" and directing the 2002 film "Old School".
George Hickenlooper was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the documentaries "The Mayor of Castro Street" and "Peggy Sue Got Married", as well as the feature film "Factory Girl".
George Jackson was a real-life prisoner and author whose life was dramatized in the 1971 film "Scarecrow" starring Al Pacino, and his story also inspired the 1972 film "Wattstax" which was a documentary about the Watts riots.
George Lucas is a renowned American filmmaker and entrepreneur, best known for creating the Star Wars and Indiana Jones franchises, and is credited with revolutionizing the film industry through his innovative use of special effects and storytelling techniques.
George Miller is a renowned Australian film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on the Mad Max franchise, including the iconic 1979 film Mad Max and its subsequent sequels, as well as the Academy Award-winning film Happy Feet.
George P. Cosmatos was a Greek-Canadian film director, best known for directing the films "Tombstone", "Rambo: First Blood Part II", and "Leviathan", as well as the cult classic "Phantoms".
George Ratliff is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his documentary films "Hell House" (2001) and "Joshua" (2007), which explore themes of faith, morality, and the human condition.
George Roy Hill was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing iconic films such as "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid", "The Sting", and "Slaughterhouse-Five".
George Sidney was a renowned American film director, producer, and actor who directed over 70 films, including classic musicals such as "Anchors Aweigh", "Show Boat", and "West Side Story", and worked with legendary stars like Gene Kelly, Frank Sinatra, and Elizabeth Taylor.
George Stevens was a renowned American film director, producer, and cinematographer who directed iconic films such as "A Place in the Sun", "Giant", "The Diary of Anne Frank", and "Shane", and was known for his meticulous attention to detail and ability to elicit strong performances from his actors.
George Tillman Jr. is a film director, producer, and screenwriter known for directing films such as "Soul Food", "Men of Honor", "Notorious", and "The Hate U Give", among others.
Georgia Hilton is a 1987 American comedy film starring Dolly Parton and Sally Field as two women who switch identities and lives, with Parton playing a con artist and Field playing a wealthy socialite.
Gerard Johnstone is a New Zealand film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2016 horror film "Housebound" and the 2018 horror film "Mortal Engines".
Gerry Lively is a British film director and producer, best known for his work on films such as "The Parent Trap" (1998), "Freaky Friday" (2003), and "Cheaper by the Dozen" (2003), among others.
Gia Coppola is an American film director, granddaughter of Francis Ford Coppola, and daughter of Roman Coppola, known for directing the 2013 film "Palo Alto", an adaptation of James Franco's short stories, which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival.
Gil Junger is a film and television director, best known for directing the 1999 teen comedy film "10 Things I Hate About You", a modern retelling of Shakespeare's "The Taming of the Shrew", starring Heath Ledger and Julia Stiles.
Gil Kenan is a Israeli-American film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the fantasy films "Monster House" (2006) and "Poltergeist" (2015), as well as the drama film "City of Ember" (2008).
Gilles Paquet-Brenner is a French film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2009 film "Wuthering Heights" and the 2011 film "The Women on the 6th Floor".
Gillian Armstrong is a renowned Australian film director, best known for her work on the 1985 film "Little Women", a critically acclaimed adaptation of Louisa May Alcott's classic novel, which earned her an Academy Award nomination for Best Director.
Gillian Robespierre is an American film director, writer, and producer known for her work on independent films such as "Obvious Child" (2014) and "Landline" (2017), which explore themes of relationships, identity, and women's experiences.
Gina Prince-Bythewood is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for her work on films such as "Love & Basketball" (2000), "The Secret Life of Bees" (2008), and "The Woman King" (2022), which have garnered critical acclaim and commercial success.
Giovanni Zelko is a Croatian film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2011 film "The Living" and the 2016 film "The High Sun", which won the Un Certain Regard award at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival.
Giuliano Montaldo is an Italian film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "Sacco e Vanzetti" (1971), "Marco Polo" (1982), and "Cristo si è fermato a Eboli" (1979).
Giuseppe Tornatore is an Italian film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his critically acclaimed films such as "Cinema Paradiso" (1989), "The Unknown to Us" (1985), and "Malèna" (2000), which have won numerous awards and have been recognized for their poetic and nostalgic portrayal of Italian culture and history.
Glen Morgan is a renowned American television writer, producer, and director, best known for his work on popular TV shows such as "The X-Files", "Space: Above and Beyond", and "Final Destination".
Glenn Ficarra is a film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "Crazy, Stupid, Love", "Focus", and "Whiskey Tango Foxtrot", often collaborating with his partner John Requa.
Gnana Rajasekaran is a Tamil film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his critically acclaimed films such as "Aarogya Oli" and "Kadhalukku Mariyadhai", which have been praised for their unique storytelling and cinematography.
Goran Dukic is a Bosnian-American film director and screenwriter, best known for his 2004 film "Wristcutters: A Love Story", a dark comedy that explores the lives of people who have died by suicide and find themselves in a purgatory-like state.
Gordon Chan is a Hong Kong film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his work on films such as "Fist of Legend", "The Big Bounce", and "New Police Story", and has collaborated with renowned actors like Jet Li and Jackie Chan.
Gore Verbinski is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the Pirates of the Caribbean franchise, as well as other successful films like The Ring and Rango, which earned him an Academy Award for Best Animated Feature.
Graham Annable is a Canadian animator, writer, and director, best known for his work on the animated TV series "Gravity Falls" and the stop-motion animated film "The Boxtrolls".
Grant Heslov is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "The Informant!" (2009), "The Ides of March" (2011), and "American Made" (2017), and is also a co-founder of the production company Smokehouse Pictures with George Clooney.
Greg Berlanti is a renowned American television producer, director, and screenwriter, best known for creating and producing several successful TV shows, including "Riverdale", "The Flash", "Arrow", "Supergirl", and "Love, Simon", and has been credited with helping to shape the modern television landscape with his work on DC Comics-based shows and LGBTQ+ representation.
Greg Coolidge is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for creating the comedy film "Ride Along" (2014) and its sequel "Ride Along 2" (2016), starring Kevin Hart and Ice Cube.
Greg Harrison is an American film director, screenwriter, and cinematographer, best known for directing the 1985 cult classic film "Gumshoe" and the 1995 film "Turbulence".
Greg Marcks is a film director and screenwriter, best known for writing and directing the 2002 thriller film "November 13th", which explores the concept of time loops and features a complex, non-linear narrative structure.
Greg Mottola is a renowned American film and television director, best known for his work on the hit TV shows "Arrested Development" and "Undeclared", as well as the films "Superbad", "Adventureland", and "Paul".
Greg Tiernan is a Canadian animator and film director, best known for his work on adult animated films and TV series, including "Thomas & Friends", "Rock Dog", and "Villainous", as well as his collaborations with Warner Bros. Animation and Netflix.
Gregor Jordan is an Australian film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the films "Two Hands" (1999), "Buffalo Soldiers" (2001), and "Metal Tornado" (2004).
Gregory Hoblit is a renowned American film director, known for his work on psychological thrillers such as "Primal Fear" (1996), "Fallen" (1998), and "Hart's War" (2002), which have garnered critical acclaim and commercial success.
Gregory Jacobs is an American film director, producer, and editor, best known for his work on the Ocean's Eleven franchise, having served as a producer and editor on the series, and directing the 2018 film "Ocean's 8".
Gregory Nava is a Mexican-American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "El Norte" (1983), "My Family" (1995), and "Selena" (1997), which won an Academy Award for Best Original Song.
Gregory Poirier is a screenwriter and film director, known for his work on films such as "Hart's War", "The Librarian: Quest for the Spear", and "The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone", and has also written for television shows like "The Agency" and "The Good Wife".
Gregory Widen is a screenwriter and director, best known for creating the 1990 film "The Prophecy" and its sequels, as well as writing the screenplay for the 1989 film "Freejack".
Griffin Dunne is an American actor, director, and producer, best known for his roles in films such as "An American Werewolf in London" (1981), "After Hours" (1985), and "The Discoverers" (2012), as well as his work on the TV series "Law & Order" and "The Good Wife".
Guillaume Canet is a French actor, director, and screenwriter, known for his roles in films such as "Tell No One", "Little White Lies", and "Love Me If You Dare", as well as his collaborations with director Christophe Barratier and actress Marion Cotillard.
Guillermo del Toro is a renowned Mexican filmmaker known for his dark, imaginative, and visually stunning films such as "Pan's Labyrinth", "Hellboy", and "Crimson Peak", which often blend elements of fantasy, horror, and science fiction.
Gurinder Chadha is a British film director, producer, and screenwriter of Indian descent, best known for directing the critically acclaimed films "Bend It Like Beckham" (2002) and "Bride & Prejudice" (2004), which blended traditional Indian culture with modern British sensibilities.
Gus Van Sant is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his distinctive filmmaking style and critically acclaimed movies such as "Good Will Hunting", "Elephant", and "Milk", which have garnered numerous awards and nominations, including the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.
Guy Hamilton is a British film director, best known for directing several James Bond films, including "Goldfinger", "Diamonds Are Forever", "Live and Let Die", and "The Man with the Golden Gun".
Guy Maddin is a Canadian filmmaker known for his surreal, dreamlike, and often experimental films that often explore themes of memory, identity, and the human condition, such as "Tales from the Gimli Hospital", "The Saddest Music in the World", and "My Winnipeg".
Guy Ritchie is a British film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his stylized and often violent crime dramas, such as "Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels", "Snatch", and "Sherlock Holmes", which have gained a cult following and critical acclaim for their unique blend of humor, style, and complex characters.
Gérard Krawczyk is a French film composer and director, best known for his work on the "Nikita" and "Taxi" film franchises, as well as composing music for numerous other films and television shows.
H.M. Coakley is a 1922 American silent Western film directed by Edward Laemmle and starring Hoot Gibson, who plays the role of a cowboy who must clear his name after being accused of murder.
Hal Haberman is an American film director, writer, and producer, best known for co-directing and co-writing the 2009 comedy film "The Brothers Solomon" alongside Charlie Hauck.
Hal Needham was a renowned American stuntman, stunt coordinator, and director, best known for his work on iconic films such as "Smokey and the Bandit", "The Dukes of Hazzard", and "Beverly Hills Cop", and was also the stunt double for John Wayne and Burt Reynolds.
Ham Tran is a Vietnamese-American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his 2007 film "Yellow Handkerchief", which was based on a short story by Pete Harris and starred Eddie Redmayne, William Hurt, and Maria Ricossa.
Hank Braxtan is a 2021 American science fiction horror film written and directed by Scott Lyus, which follows a group of friends who discover a mysterious alien artifact that unleashes a terrifying force that threatens to destroy their lives.
Hans Canosa is a Cuban-American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "Rumble Fish" (1983), "The Outsiders" (1983), and "Streets of Fire" (1984), which showcased his unique visual style and ability to capture the essence of youth culture and rebellion.
Hans Petter Moland is a Norwegian film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on films such as "A Somewhat Gentle Man" and "Out Stealing Horses", which have received critical acclaim and numerous awards.
Hao Ning is a Chinese film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "The Pluto Moment" and "The Wasted Times", which have received critical acclaim and won numerous awards at international film festivals.
Harald Zwart is a Norwegian film director, known for directing films such as "Agent Cody Banks", "Hitch", and "The Pink Panther 2", as well as the "Karate Kid" and "Just Like Heaven" movies.
Hark Tsui is a renowned Hong Kong film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his visually stunning and often fantastical films such as "A Chinese Ghost Story" and "The Blade".
Harley Cokeliss is a British film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1985 science fiction film "Wizards" and the 1990 horror film "Edge of Honor".
Harmage Singh Kalirai is a British film producer and director, best known for his work on the 2011 film "The Iron Lady", which won the Academy Award for Best Actress for Meryl Streep's portrayal of Margaret Thatcher.
Harmony Korine is a American filmmaker, writer, and artist known for his unconventional and often provocative works, including the films "Kids", "Gummo", "Julien Donkey-Boy", and "Spring Breakers", which have garnered both critical acclaim and controversy for their unflinching portrayals of youth culture and societal ills.
Harold Becker is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his work on films such as "The Lost Weekend", "The Big Bus", "Taps", "Fletch", "Runaway", "The Boost", "City Hall", and "Executive Target".
Harold Cronk is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the Christian-themed films "God's Not Dead" (2014) and "God's Not Dead 2" (2016).
Harold Ramis was a renowned American film director, writer, and actor, best known for his work on comedies such as "Groundhog Day", "Caddyshack", "National Lampoon's Vacation", and "Ghostbusters", and was also a key figure in the development of the "Second City" comedy troupe.
Harry Elfont is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1995 comedy film "Can't Hardly Wait" and co-creating the TV series "Ugly Betty" with his wife, Deborah Kaplan.
Harry F. Millarde was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter who worked in the early days of Hollywood, directing over 100 films, including the 1925 silent film "The Unholy Three" starring Lon Chaney.
Hart Bochner is a Canadian actor, best known for his roles in films such as "Die Hard" (1988) as Harry Ellis, a arrogant and obnoxious corporate executive, and "WarGames" (1983) as Dr. Stephen Falken, a brilliant computer scientist.
Henry Bean is a film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the 1997 film "The Believer", a drama that explores themes of anti-Semitism and identity crisis.
Henry Hobson is a 1999 American comedy-drama film directed by Brett Ratner, starring Paul Rudd, Giovanni Ribisi, and Laura Dern, which tells the story of a young man who inherits his father's funeral home and must navigate his new responsibilities while also trying to win the heart of his childhood sweetheart.
Henry Jaglom is a British-American film director, writer, and actor known for his improvisational and experimental approach to filmmaking, having directed over 20 films, including "A Safe Place", "Tracks", and "Can She Bake a Cherry Pie", which often explore themes of relationships, identity, and the human condition.
Henry King was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter who directed over 100 films, including the Academy Award-winning "Twelve O'Clock High" and "The Gunfighter", and was known for his versatility in directing a wide range of genres, from dramas to westerns to comedies.
Henry Koster was a German-American film director who directed over 60 films, including the classic musicals "The Robe" and "The Music Man", and was known for his ability to balance drama and comedy in his films.
Henry Selick is a renowned American animator and film director, best known for his work on stop-motion animated films such as "The Nightmare Before Christmas" (1993), "James and the Giant Peach" (1996), and "Coraline" (2009).
Herbert Ross was a renowned American film director, producer, and choreographer, known for directing iconic films such as "The Goodbye Girl", "Nuts", "Steel Magnolias", and "Footloose", among many others.
Hideaki Anno is a Japanese film director, screenwriter, and animator, best known for his work on the iconic anime series "Neon Genesis Evangelion" and the live-action film "Shin Godzilla".
Hironobu Sakaguchi is a renowned Japanese video game designer and director, best known for creating the iconic Final Fantasy series, which has become a beloved and influential franchise in the world of gaming.
Hitoshi Matsumoto is a Japanese comedian, actor, and director, best known for his work on the popular Japanese TV show "Eleven People" and his unique brand of absurdist comedy, which has gained a cult following worldwide.
Howard Deutch is a film director known for directing several iconic 80s and 90s movies, including "The Great Outdoors", "Pretty in Pink", "Some Kind of Wonderful", and "European Vacation".
Howard Hawks was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his work on classic films such as "Rio Bravo", "The Big Sleep", "Red River", and "His Girl Friday", and is often referred to as one of the greatest directors of Hollywood's Golden Age.
Howard Hughes was a successful businessman, investor, and filmmaker who produced and directed iconic movies such as "Hell's Angels" (1930), "Scarface" (1932), "42nd Street" (1933), and "The Outlaw" (1943), and was also known for his obsessive-compulsive disorder and eccentric behavior.
Howard Zieff was an American film director, known for his work on films such as "My Girl" (1991), "Can't Buy Me Love" (1987), and "Unfaithfully Yours" (1984), and was particularly recognized for his ability to balance humor and drama in his storytelling.
Hoyt Yeatman is a visual effects supervisor and director, best known for his work on films such as "Deep Rising" (1998), "The Core" (2003), and "Battle: Los Angeles" (2011).
Hsiao-Hsien Hou is a renowned Taiwanese film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his visually stunning and contemplative films that often explore themes of identity, memory, and the human condition, such as "A City of Sadness", "Flowers of Shanghai", and "The Assassin".
Huck Botko is a writer, director, and producer who is best known for creating the popular comedy troupe The Lonely Island, alongside Andy Samberg and Akiva Schaffer, and has written and directed several films and TV shows, including "Hot Rod" and "Brooklyn Nine-Nine".
Hue Rhodes is a 1999 American drama film directed by Scott Elliott, starring Forest Whitaker, Angela Bassett, and Ving Rhames, which tells the story of a former convict who returns to his hometown and tries to reconnect with his estranged family and friends.
Hugh Hudson is a British film director, best known for directing the iconic 1981 film "Chariots of Fire", which won four Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Director.
Hugh Johnson is a renowned British wine writer, author of the classic book "The Wine Atlas" and "The Story of Wine", and a respected authority on wine and viticulture, who has written extensively on the subject and has been a prominent figure in the wine world for many decades.
Hugh Wilson is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the iconic comedy films "The First Wives Club" (1996), "Beverly Hills Cop II" (1987), and "Police Academy" (1984).
Hunter Richards is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 2007 American drama film "The Lookout", played by Joseph Gordon-Levitt, who becomes embroiled in a complex web of relationships and crime after a traumatic brain injury.

Ingmar Bergman was a renowned Swedish film director, writer, and producer who is widely regarded as one of the most influential and important filmmakers of all time, known for his introspective and emotionally charged films that explored themes of mortality, faith, and the human condition, such as "The Seventh Seal", "Persona", and "Fanny and Alexander".
Inna Evlannikova is a Russian actress who played the role of Ksenia in the 2014 Russian drama film "The Method", which was based on the novel of the same name by Andrey Kurkov.

Jake Scott is a British film director, known for his work on films such as "Platoon" and "Blow Out", and is the son of director Ridley Scott.
Jamaa Fanaka was an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the 1979 film "Penitentiary" and its 1981 sequel, which were low-budget, exploitation-style prison dramas that gained a cult following.
