Jamel Debbouze is a French actor, comedian, and musician of Moroccan descent, best known for his roles in films such as "Amélie" and "The Science of Sleep".
James Algar was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter who is best known for his work on Disney's True-Life Adventure series, including the Academy Award-winning film "Seal Island" (1948) and "The Living Desert" (1953).
James Bidgood is a American filmmaker and photographer, best known for his 1968 experimental film "Pink Flamings", a campy and surreal exploration of male sexuality and identity, which has become a cult classic and a staple of underground cinema.
James Bobin is a British film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the Muppets films "The Muppets" (2011) and "Muppets Most Wanted" (2014), as well as the TV series "Da Ali G Show" and "Flight of the Conchords".
James Bridges was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the iconic films "The China Syndrome", "The Paper Chase", and "Urban Cowboy".
James Cameron is a renowned film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his groundbreaking and visually stunning films such as "The Terminator", "Aliens", "Titanic", and "Avatar", which have collectively grossed over $2 billion at the box office and have won numerous awards, including several Academy Awards.
James Cox is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on films such as "Wonderland" (2003), "3:10 to Yuma" (2007), and "Brighton Rock" (2010).
James David Pasternak is a Canadian film producer and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 1984 film "The Ice Storm", which was directed by Ang Lee and won several Academy Awards.
James DeMonaco is a screenwriter and director known for creating the popular horror franchise "The Purge", which has spawned four films and a television series, and is known for its unique concept of a 12-hour period where all crimes, including murder, are legal.
James Dodson is a golf journalist and author who wrote the memoir "Final Rounds: A Father, a Son, the Game of Golf, and the Illusion of Life" which was adapted into the 1999 film "The Greatest Game Ever Played" starring Shia LaBeouf and Josh Flitter.
James Fargo is an American film director and producer, best known for directing the 1982 comedy film "Raiders of the Lost Ark" and the 1985 film "Fletch Lives".
James Foley was an American journalist who was kidnapped and beheaded by the Islamic State in 2014, and his tragic story was later portrayed in the documentary film "Jim: The James Foley Story" (2016).
James Frawley was an American film and television director, best known for directing the 1978 musical fantasy film "The Muppet Movie" and the 1981 fantasy film "Dragonslayer".
James Gartner is a German film director, best known for directing the 2005 film "Hitch" starring Will Smith, Eva Mendes, and Kevin James.
James Gray is a critically acclaimed American film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his visually stunning and thought-provoking films such as "The Yards", "We Own the Night", "Two Lovers", "The Immigrant", and "Ad Astra", which often explore themes of identity, morality, and the human condition.
James Gunn is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for creating the Guardians of the Galaxy franchise and writing the script for the DC Extended Universe's Peacemaker series.
James Isaac is a film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the horror films "Jason X" (2001), "The Prophecy II" (1998), and "Demonic Toys" (1992).
James Ivory is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on Merchant Ivory Productions, a film production company he co-founded with Ismail Merchant, and for directing films such as "A Room with a View", "Howards End", and "The Remains of the Day", which have garnered numerous Academy Award nominations and wins.
James Kerwin is a film director, writer, and producer, best known for his work on the 2007 science fiction film "The Gene Generation" and the 2011 horror film "The Night Before Halloween".
James L. Brooks is a renowned American film and television producer, writer, and director, best known for his work on iconic films such as "The Simpsons," "Taxi," "Terms of Endearment," "Broadcast News," and "As Good as It Gets," earning him multiple Academy Award nominations and wins.
James Mangold is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing films such as "Walk the Line", "3:10 to Yuma", and "Logan", which is part of the X-Men film series.
James Mangold is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his work on films such as "Heavy" (1995), "Girl, Interrupted" (1999), "Kate & Leopold" (2001), "Walk the Line" (2005), "3:10 to Yuma" (2007), "Knight and Day" (2010), "The Wolverine" (2013), and "Logan" (2017), which received widespread critical acclaim and earned him numerous awards and nominations.
James Marsh is a British film director, known for his work on films such as "The Theory of Everything", "We Need to Talk About Kevin", and "Widows", which have received critical acclaim and numerous award nominations.
James Mather is a British screenwriter and director, best known for co-writing and directing the 2012 sci-fi thriller film "Lockout" starring Guy Pearce and Maggie Grace.
James McTeigue is an Australian film director, best known for his work on the V for Vendetta (2005) and Ninja Assassin (2009) movies, both of which were critically acclaimed and commercially successful.
James Melkonian is a film editor and cinematographer who has worked on several notable movies, including the 2014 film "The Homesman" starring Hilary Swank and Tommy Lee Jones, and the 2017 film "The Glass Castle" starring Brie Larson and Woody Harrelson.
James Mottern is an American screenwriter and film director, best known for writing and directing the 2009 film "Trucker", a drama starring Michelle Monaghan and Nathan Fillion.
James Nunn is a British film director and producer, best known for his work on low-budget action films such as "Rogue Warrior: Robot Rebellion" and "Storage 24", as well as the horror film "Tower Block".
James O'Brien is a British journalist and author, best known for his work as a presenter on the BBC's Newsnight and his appearances on the BBC's Question Time, as well as his book "How to Stop Losing Your Sh*t with People".
James Ponsoldt is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his work on coming-of-age dramas such as "Smashed", "The Spectacular Now", and "The Circle", often exploring themes of youth, identity, and technology.
James Schamus is a renowned American film producer, screenwriter, and director, best known for his work on films such as "Brotherhood of the Wolf", "The Ice Storm", and "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon", and has received numerous awards and nominations for his contributions to the film industry.
James Toback is an American film director, writer, and actor, known for directing films such as "Fingers" (1978), "The Pick-up Artist" (1987), and "Black and White" (1999), as well as writing and directing the critically acclaimed biographical drama "The Big Lebowski" (1998).
James Wan is a Malaysian-born Australian film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his work on horror films such as "Saw", "Insidious", and "The Conjuring" franchises, as well as superhero movies like "Aquaman" and "Justice League".
James Watkins is a British film director, best known for directing the horror films "Eden Lake" (2008) and "The Woman in Black" (2012), which was a commercial success and received positive reviews from critics.
James Wong is a Hong Kong-born American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the horror films "The Faculty" (1998), "Final Destination" (2000), and "Final Destination 3" (2006).
Jamie Babbit is a American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for her work on films such as "But I'm a Cheerleader" (1999) and "Itty Bitty Titty Committee" (2007), which have been praised for their unique blend of humor, satire, and LGBTQ+ representation.
Jamie Thraves is a British film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the critically acclaimed films "My Summer of Love" (2004) and "The Low Down" (2000), as well as his collaborations with British indie rock band Coldplay on several music videos.
Jamie Travis is a Canadian film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2011 film "Me and You and Everyone We Know" and the 2013 film "For Those Who Can Tell No Tales".
Jamin Winans is a writer and director, best known for his 2007 sci-fi short film "I Know What You Did Last Summer: Remix", which was a re-imagining of the 1997 horror film "I Know What You Did Last Summer".
Jan de Bont is a Dutch film director, producer, and cinematographer, best known for directing the blockbuster films "Speed", "Twister", and "The Haunting", as well as working on films like "Turkish Delight" and "The Living Daylights".
Jane Campion is a renowned New Zealand film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for her critically acclaimed films such as "The Piano" and "The Power of the Dog", which have earned her numerous awards and nominations, including the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.
Janusz Kaminski is a Polish cinematographer, best known for his collaborations with director Steven Spielberg on films such as "Schindler's List", "Saving Private Ryan", and "Catch Me If You Can", earning him numerous awards and nominations, including three Academy Awards for Best Cinematography.
Jared Hess is a film director, writer, and producer known for his quirky and offbeat comedies, including Napoleon Dynamite, Nacho Libre, and Gentlemen Broncos.
Jason Alexander is a renowned American actor, best known for his iconic role as George Costanza in the hit TV sitcom "Seinfeld" (1989-1998).
Jason Bateman is a renowned American actor, director, and producer, best known for his roles in TV shows such as "Arrested Development" and "Ozark", as well as films like "Juno", "Horrible Bosses", and "This Is Where I Leave You".
Jason Connery is the son of legendary actor Sean Connery, and he has also pursued an acting career, appearing in films such as "Robin Hood" and "The Devil's Whore".
Jason Eisener is a Canadian film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the horror film "Hobo with a Shotgun" (2011) and the comedy-horror film "Tusk" (2014), both of which were written and produced by Kevin Smith.
Jason Friedberg is a American screenwriter, director, and producer, best known for writing and directing a series of low-budget parody films, including "Date Movie", "Epic Movie", "Meet the Spartans", and "Vampires Suck", which have been met with largely negative reviews from critics and audiences alike.
Jason Moore is an American film director and producer, best known for directing the 2014 comedy film "Pitch Perfect" and its 2017 sequel "Pitch Perfect 3", as well as the 2019 film "Marmaduke".
Jason Naumann is a character played by actor Jason Bateman in the 2004 film "Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story".
Jason Reitman is a Canadian-American film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his work on films such as "Juno", "Up in the Air", "Young Adult", and "Ghostbusters: Afterlife", which are often praised for their witty dialogue, relatable characters, and nuanced exploration of human relationships.
Jaume Balagueró is a Spanish film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on horror films such as "Rec" and "Sleep Tight", which have gained international recognition for their tense and suspenseful storytelling.
Jaume Collet-Serra is a Spanish film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his work on thrillers and action movies, including "House of Wax", "Orphan", "Unknown", "Non-Stop", "The Shallows", and "Jungle Cruise".
Jay Chandrasekhar is an American actor, writer, and director, best known for being a member of the comedy troupe The Broken Lizard, and for directing and starring in films such as "Super Troopers", "Beerfest", and "The Dukes of Hazzard".
Jay Duplass is an American actor, writer, and director, known for his roles in TV shows such as "Transparent" and "Togetherness", as well as films like "Safety Not Guaranteed" and "Jeff, Who Lives at Home", often collaborating with his brother Mark Duplass on creative projects.
Jay Levey is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1985 comedy film "Trading Places" starring Eddie Murphy and Dan Aykroyd.
Jay Oliva is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on animated and live-action films, including the critically acclaimed animated series "Justice League: The Flashpoint Paradox" and the DC Comics film "Batman: The Dark Knight Returns".
Jay Roach is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on the Austin Powers film series, Meet the Parents, and the HBO series Recount and Game Change.
Jay Russell is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for directing films such as "My Dog Skip" (2000), "Ladder 49" (2004), and "The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep" (2007).
Je-kyu Kang is a South Korean film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2003 film "The Classic" and the 2013 film "The Flu".
Jean-François Richet is a French film director, best known for directing the 2005 remake of "Assault on Precinct 13" and the 2007 film "Messiah".
Jean-Jacques Annaud is a French film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing films such as "The Name of the Rose", "Seven Years in Tibet", and "Wolf Totem", which have received critical acclaim and numerous awards.
Jean-Luc Godard was a French-Swiss film director, screenwriter, and producer who was a leading figure in the French New Wave movement, known for his innovative and influential films such as "Breathless", "Vivre sa vie", and "Contempt".
Jean-Marc Vallée is a Canadian film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his work on critically acclaimed films such as "Dallas Buyers Club", "Wild", and "Big Little Lies", as well as his distinctive visual style and ability to elicit powerful performances from his actors.
Jean-Marie Poiré is a French film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the 1993 comedy film "Les Visiteurs" which became a huge success in France and launched the career of French actor Christian Clavier.
Jean-Paul Rappeneau is a French film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the Academy Award-winning film "A Good Year" (2006) and the critically acclaimed films "Cyrano de Bergerac" (1990) and "Indochine" (1992).
Jean-Pierre Jeunet is a French film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his visually striking and often quirky films, such as "Amélie", "Delicatessen", and "The City of Lost Children", which often blend elements of fantasy, romance, and dark humor.
Jeannot Szwarc is a Polish-American film director, best known for directing the horror film "Jaws 2" (1978), as well as the comedy films "Killer Bees" (1978), "Somewhere in Time" (1980), and "Supergirl" (1984).
Jeb Stuart was a Confederate general during the American Civil War, best known for his role in the Battle of Gettysburg, where he led Pickett's Charge, a disastrous and ill-fated assault on the Union positions on Cemetery Ridge.
Jee-woon Kim is a South Korean film director and screenwriter known for his work on films such as "A Tale of Two Sisters", "The Good, the Bad, the Weird", and "I Saw the Devil", which have gained international recognition for their unique blend of genres, dark humor, and social commentary.
Jeff Burr is an American film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the horror films "From the Dead of Night" (1989), "Puppet Master III: Toulon's Revenge" (1991), and "Dust Devil" (1992).
Jeff Crook is a writer and director known for his work on horror movies, including the 2005 film "The Ringer" and the 2007 film "Wolves Bayonets", which he co-wrote with his wife, Mandy Martin.
Jeff Franklin is an American television writer, producer, and director, best known for creating the popular sitcom "Full House" and its spin-off "Fuller House", which aired from 1987 to 1995 and 2016 to 2020, respectively.
Jeff Garlin is an American comedian, actor, and director, best known for his roles as Jeff Goldberg in the ABC sitcom "Curb Your Enthusiasm" and as Murray Goldberg in the ABC sitcom "The Goldbergs".
Jeff Kanew is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the 1984 comedy film "Fletch" starring Chevy Chase and the 1987 comedy film "Troop Beverly Hills" starring Shelley Long.
Jeff Lowell is an American screenwriter and producer, best known for creating the TV shows "Two Guys, a Girl" and "The Winner", as well as writing the screenplay for the 2003 comedy film "Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd".
Jeff Nathanson is a renowned American screenwriter and film director, best known for his work on the Indiana Jones franchise, including the scripts for "Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull" (2008) and "Indiana Jones 5" (2023), as well as the Disney-Pixar film "Rush Hour" (1998).
Jeff Nichols is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his critically acclaimed films such as "Take Shelter", "Mud", "Midnight Special", and "Loving", which often explore themes of family, identity, and the American South.

Jeff Tremaine is an American journalist, author, and filmmaker, best known for co-creating the Jackass franchise, which includes the TV series, films, and other media, and has also directed several other films, including "Baptist Boy" and "Street Trash".
Jeff Wadlow is a American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the horror movies "Freddy vs. Jason" (2003), "The Rules of Attraction" (2002), and "Truth or Dare" (2018).

Jennifer Wynne Farmer is a Canadian actress, best known for her role as the voice of the titular character in the 1984 animated film "The Care Bears Movie".
Jennifer Yuh Nelson is a Korean-American film director, animator, and screenwriter, best known for co-directing the Kung Fu Panda 2 and solo-directing the Kung Fu Panda 3, becoming the first Asian American woman to direct a DreamWorks Animation feature film.
Jeremy Brock is a British screenwriter and film director, best known for co-writing the screenplay for the 1997 film "Shakespeare in Love" alongside Marc Norman, for which they won the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.
Jeremy Degruson is a Belgian animator and director, best known for his work on the animated film "Ernest & Celestine" (2012), which won the César Award for Best Animated Feature Film.
Jeremy Leven is a film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on romantic dramas such as "The Notebook" (2004) and "My Best Friend's Wedding" (1997).
Jeremy Saulnier is a American film director, writer, and cinematographer known for his work on critically acclaimed indie thrillers such as "Blue Ruin" (2013), "Green Room" (2015), and "Hold the Dark" (2018), which have garnered him a reputation for crafting tense, suspenseful, and often violent stories that explore themes of trauma, morality, and the human condition.

Jesse Vaughan is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 2014 film "Nightcrawler", played by Jake Gyllenhaal, who becomes obsessed with capturing violent and gruesome footage for a local news station.

Jeta Amata is a Nigerian film director, producer, and actor who has directed several Nollywood films, including "The Figurine" and "Black Gold", and has won numerous awards for his work in the Nigerian film industry.

Jim Amatulli is a film producer and writer who has worked on several movies, including the 2019 film "Good Boys" and the 2020 film "The Map of Tiny Perfect Things".
Jim Chuchu is a Kenyan filmmaker and writer, best known for creating the popular web series "Watu Wote: All of Us" and "Soko Sonko", which have gained international recognition for their thought-provoking and socially conscious storytelling.
Jim Fall is an American film director, best known for directing the 1999 comedy film "Can't Hardly Wait" and the 2001 comedy film "Whatever It Takes".
Jim Field Smith is a British film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2008 comedy film "She's Out of My League" and the 2011 comedy film "Nacho Libre".
Jim Goddard is a Canadian film director and producer, best known for his work on the 1985 film "The Surrogate" and the 1992 film "The Adjuster", both of which starred Bruce Greenwood.
Jim Hanon is a film director and producer, best known for directing the documentary "End of the Spear" (2005), which tells the true story of the lives of Steve Saint and his family, who were missionaries in Ecuador and were affected by the death of their friend Nate Saint in 1956.
Jim Issa is a character from the 2013 American comedy film "We're the Millers", played by actor Nick Offerman, who portrays a small-time pot dealer and friend of the main character Dave.

Jim Mickle is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his work on horror and thriller films such as "Stake Land", "We Are What We Are", and "Cold in July".
Jim Sheridan is a renowned Irish film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his emotionally charged and critically acclaimed films such as "My Left Foot", "The Field", "In the Name of the Father", and "Brothers", which have earned him numerous awards and nominations, including three Academy Award nominations for Best Director.
Jim Sonzero is a film editor and producer, best known for his work on the horror movie franchise "Saw" and the thriller film "The Strangers".
Jimmy Hayward is an American animator, director, and screenwriter, best known for directing the animated films "Hoodwinked" (2005) and "Alpha and Omega" (2010), as well as co-directing the stop-motion animated film "Free Birds" (2013).

Joan Chen is a Chinese-American actress, director, and producer who has appeared in numerous films and television shows, including "The Last Emperor", "Twin Peaks", and "The Home Song Stories", and has won several awards for her work, including a Golden Horse Award and a Hong Kong Film Award.
Jodie Foster is a renowned American actress, director, and producer who has won two Academy Awards for her performances in "The Silence of the Lambs" and "The Accused", and has also directed several films, including "Little Man Tate" and "Panic Room".

Joe Carnahan is a American film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his gritty and intense films such as "Narc", "Smokin' Aces", and "The Grey", which often explore themes of violence, morality, and redemption.
Joe Cornish is a British filmmaker, actor, and comedian, best known for co-founding the comedy troupe Adam and Joe and directing the 2011 sci-fi horror film "Attack the Block".
Joe Dante is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on cult classics such as "Piranha", "The Howling", "Gremlins", and "Innerspace", as well as his collaborations with Roger Corman and the Amblin Entertainment company.
Joe Johnston is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his work on iconic movies such as "Raiders of the Lost Ark", "The Rocketeer", "Jumanji", and "Captain America: The First Avenger", among others.
Joe Nussbaum is an American film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2004 teen comedy film "Sleepover" and the 2005 Disney Channel Original Movie "Teen Spirit".
Joe Pytka is a renowned American film and television director, best known for his work on numerous high-profile commercials and music videos, as well as directing films such as "The Wiz" (1978), "The Greatest American Hero" (1981), and "Michael Jordan to the Max" (2000).
Joe Roth is a renowned American film producer and former studio executive, known for producing blockbuster films such as "The Lion King", "Alice in Wonderland", and "Maleficent", as well as serving as the CEO of 20th Century Fox and Disney's Hollywood Pictures.
Joe Swanberg is an American independent film director, writer, and actor known for his mumblecore genre films, such as "Hannah Takes the Stairs" and "Drinking Buddies", which often focus on the relationships and everyday lives of young adults.
Joe Wright is a British film director known for his work on films such as "Pride & Prejudice", "Atonement", and "Hanna", often incorporating complex characters, atmospheric settings, and emotional depth into his cinematic storytelling.
Joel Anderson is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 1976 horror film "It's Alive", played by John Pankow, in which he is a young father whose newborn baby is a mutant that kills several people.
Joel Coen is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work with his brother Ethan Coen, with whom he has collaborated on numerous critically acclaimed and award-winning films, including "Fargo", "The Big Lebowski", "O Brother, Where Art Thou?", and "No Country for Old Men".
Joel Gallen is an American film director and producer, best known for directing the comedy films "Super Troopers" (2001), "Zoolander" (2001), and "Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues" (2013).
Joel Schumacher was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing iconic films such as "The Lost Boys", "Flatliners", "Batman Forever", and "Batman & Robin", as well as "Phone Booth" and "Tigerland".
Joel Zwick is a Greek-American film and television director, best known for directing the 1995 comedy film "My Big Fat Greek Wedding", which became a surprise hit and launched the career of its star, Nia Vardalos.
Joey Lauren Adams is an American actress and comedian, best known for her roles in films such as "Clerks" (1994), "Chasing Amy" (1997), and "Angus" (1995), and for her critically acclaimed performance in the 1997 film "The Suburbans".
John A. Davis is an American animator, writer, and director, best known for creating the animated film "Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius" and its subsequent television series.
John Blanchard is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 1970 film "Airport" and its sequels, played by Charlton Heston, who is a rugged and experienced air traffic controller tasked with ensuring the safe takeoff and landing of a plane despite a series of catastrophic events.
John Bonito is a film editor and director, best known for his work on the Marvel Cinematic Universe, including the editing of Iron Man, Captain America: The First Avenger, and Thor.
John Boorman is a British film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing iconic films such as "Point Blank" (1967), "Deliverance" (1972), "Excalibur" (1981), and "Hope and Glory" (1987), which showcased his versatility and mastery of various genres.
John Cameron Mitchell is a American actor, writer, and director, best known for his work on the film "Hedwig and the Angry Inch" and the TV series "Girls", and has also appeared in films such as "Shortbus" and "Rabbit Hole".
John Carney is an Irish film director, screenwriter, and musician, best known for directing the Academy Award-winning film "Once" (2007), a romantic musical drama starring Glen Hansard and Markéta Irglová.
John Carpenter is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and composer known for his work on iconic horror movies such as Halloween, The Fog, and The Thing, as well as cult classics like Escape from New York and Big Trouble in Little China.
John Cornell was an Australian actor, writer, and producer, best known for creating the popular Australian television series "The Paul Hogan Show" and "Crocodile Dundee" film franchise, which catapulted Paul Hogan to international stardom.
John Cromwell was an American film director, actor, and screenwriter who directed over 60 films, including the classic dramas "Of Mice and Men" (1939) and "Since You Went Away" (1944), and was nominated for three Academy Awards for Best Director.
John Crowley is an American film director, known for his work on films such as "The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai Across the 8th Dimension" (1984), "Unstrung Heroes" (1995), and "We Are Marshall" (2006).
John Curran is an American film director, known for directing films such as "Praise" (1998), "We Don't Live Here Anymore" (2004), and "Me and Orson Welles" (2008), which have received critical acclaim for their nuanced portrayals of complex characters and relationships.
John D. Hancock is an American film director, best known for directing the 1975 film "Rocky Horror Picture Show" and the 1980 film "Let's Get Harry".
John Dahl is a film director and screenwriter known for his work on neo-noir thrillers such as "Kill Me Again" (1989), "Unforgettable" (1996), and "Rounders" (1998), as well as the crime drama "The Great Raid" (2005).
John Duigan is an Australian film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on films such as "The Year My Voice Broke" (1987), "Flirting" (1991), and "Sirens" (1994), which often explored themes of adolescence, identity, and coming-of-age.
John Eng is a Chinese-American film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the Academy Award-winning animated short film "Mumford" (1999) and the animated feature film "The Triplets of Belleville" (2003).
John Erick Dowdle is a film director, writer, and producer known for his work on tense and suspenseful thrillers such as "Quarantine", "The Poughkeepsie Tapes", and "No Escape", often exploring themes of confinement, isolation, and the breakdown of societal norms.
John Ford was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter who is often regarded as one of the most influential and iconic directors in the history of cinema, known for his work on classic Westerns such as "The Searchers" and "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance", as well as his collaborations with John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara.
John Fortenberry is an American film and television director, best known for his work on the TV series "Boy Meets World" and "Sabrina the Teenage Witch".
John Francis Daley is an American actor, writer, and director, best known for his roles in the TV series "Bones" and "Freaks and Geeks", as well as co-writing and directing the comedy films "Horrible Bosses" and "Game Night".
John Frankenheimer was a renowned American film director, known for his work on psychological thrillers and dramas, including "The Manchurian Candidate", "Seven Days in May", and "Ronin", which showcased his expertise in crafting tense, suspenseful narratives and exploring themes of paranoia, politics, and human psychology.
John G. Avildsen was an American film director, best known for directing the iconic boxing film "Rocky" (1976) and its first sequel "Rocky II" (1979), as well as the coming-of-age comedy "The Karate Kid" (1984).
John Gatins is an American screenwriter, producer, and director, best known for his work on films such as "Coach Carter", "Summer Catch", and "Flight", for which he received an Academy Award nomination for Best Original Screenplay.
John Glen is a British film director, best known for directing seven James Bond films, including "For Your Eyes Only", "Octopussy", "A View to a Kill", "The Living Daylights", "Licence to Kill", "GoldenEye", and "Tomorrow Never Dies".
John Gray is a renowned American astrologer and author, best known for his book "Men Are from Mars, Women Are from Venus", which explores the differences in male and female behavior and communication styles.
John Gulager is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the horror film "Piranha 3DD" and the TV series "Fear Itself".
John H. Lee was a Korean-American film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1985 film "A Single Spark", which was the first Korean film to be selected for the Un Certain Regard category at the Cannes Film Festival.
John Hamburg is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the films "Meet the Parents" (2000), "Zoolander" (2001), "Along Came Polly" (2004), and "I Love You, Man" (2009).
John Herzfeld is a film director, writer, and producer, best known for directing the 1997 psychological thriller film "2 Days in the Valley", which starred Eric Stoltz, Jeff Daniels, and Cameron Diaz.
John Hillcoat is a Australian film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his work on films such as "The Proposition", "The Road", and "Triple Nine", often exploring themes of violence, morality, and the human condition.
John Hoffman is a film producer and screenwriter, best known for his work on the TV series "What We Do in the Shadows" and the film "What We Do in the Shadows" (2014), which was based on the 2014 mockumentary film of the same name directed by Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi.
John Huston was a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and actor, known for his distinctive visual style and iconic films such as "The Maltese Falcon", "The African Queen", and "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre".
John Laing is a British film producer and director, best known for his work on the 1971 film "The Go-Between" and the 1984 film "The Killing Fields", which won seven Academy Awards including Best Picture.
John Landis is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on iconic films such as "The Blues Brothers", "An American Werewolf in London", and "Coming to America".
John Lasseter is a renowned American animator, film director, and producer who is best known for his work at Pixar Animation Studios, where he directed and produced some of the studio's most successful films, including "Toy Story," "A Bug's Life," "Toy Story 2," and "Cars."
John Lee Hancock is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for his work on films such as "The Blind Side", "The Alamo", and "Saving Mr. Banks", among others.
John Luessenhop is a Canadian film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2012 film "Takers" and the 2013 film "Turbine".
John Madden was a renowned American football coach and sportscaster who is best known for his work as the head coach of the Oakland Raiders in the National Football League (NFL) and for his iconic video game franchise, Madden NFL, which was named after him.
John Maybury is a British film and television director, known for his work on films such as "Love is the Devil" and "The Nine Lives of Tomas Katz", as well as TV shows like "The State Within" and "The Politician's Husband".
John McNaughton is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his critically acclaimed and controversial debut film "Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer" (1986), which is often cited as one of the greatest independent films of all time.

John Milius is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and actor, best known for his work on iconic films such as "Apocalypse Now", "Conan the Barbarian", and "Red Dawn", and is often credited with coining the term "jingoism" to describe his patriotic and militaristic themes in his films.

Kasi Lemmons is an American film director, screenwriter, and actress, best known for directing the critically acclaimed film "Eve's Bayou" (1997) and writing the screenplay for the biographical drama "Ray" (2004), which earned her an Academy Award nomination for Best Original Screenplay.

Kate Barker-Froyland is an American film composer, known for her work on films such as "Frances Ha" and "Listen Up Philip", and has also composed music for various television shows and documentaries.
Kate Connor is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 2019 American comedy-drama film "Booksmart", played by Kaitlyn Dever, who embarks on a wild adventure with her best friend Amy to break the rules and have the time of their lives on the eve of graduation.
Katherine Brooks is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 2004 romantic drama film "A Walk to Remember", played by Mandy Moore, who falls in love with a charismatic and popular high school student, Landon Carter, despite being diagnosed with terminal leukemia.
Katherine Dieckmann is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for her work on films such as "Motherhood" (2009), "A Good Baby" (2000), and "Strange Weather" (2013).
Kathryn Bigelow is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for her work on films such as "The Hurt Locker", "Zero Dark Thirty", and "Point Break", which have garnered her numerous awards and nominations, including the Academy Award for Best Director.
Katja von Garnier is a German film director and screenwriter, best known for her work on films such as "Bandits" (1997), "Abgehen" (1997), and "Blut und Eis" (2002).
Katsuhiro Otomo is a renowned Japanese manga artist and film director, best known for creating the iconic cyberpunk manga and anime series "Akira" and directing the 1988 animated film adaptation of the same name, which is widely regarded as a groundbreaking and influential work in the science fiction genre.
Kay Pollak is a Swedish film director, screenwriter, and actress, best known for directing the 2003 romantic drama film "Chocolat" starring Juliette Binoche and Johnny Depp.
Keenen Ivory Wayans is a renowned American actor, writer, and director, best known for creating and starring in the popular sketch comedy show "In Living Color" and directing the successful horror movie "Scary Movie".
Keith Gordon is an American actor, director, and producer, best known for his roles in films such as "Christine" (1983), "The Legend of Billie Jean" (1985), and "Back to the Future Part II" (1989).
Keith Parmer is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 2000 film "Pitch Black", played by Vin Diesel, who is a spaceship pilot who crash-lands on a distant planet with a group of survivors and must fight for survival against deadly creatures.
Kelly Makin is a British television director, best known for directing the popular British sitcom "Absolutely Fabulous" and the 1997 film "Spice World", the official film of the British pop girl group Spice Girls.
Kelly Reichardt is a critically acclaimed American film director, known for her slow-burning, atmospheric, and often minimalist films that explore themes of isolation, loneliness, and the human condition, such as "Old Joy", "Wendy and Lucy", "Meek's Cutoff", and "Certain Women".
Ken Annakin was a British film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the first installment of the Disney trilogy "The Three Lives of Thomasina" and "The Swiss Family Robinson", as well as being one of the first directors to work on the "Indiana Jones" franchise.
Ken Del Conte is a former professional wrestler who competed in the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE) during the 1980s and is best known for his feuds with wrestlers such as Hulk Hogan and Randy Savage.
Ken Kwapis is a film and television director, known for his work on movies such as "The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants", "He's Just Not That Into You", and "Big Miracle", as well as TV shows like "The Bernie Mac Show" and "The Office".
Ken Loach is a renowned British film director and screenwriter known for his gritty, socially conscious, and often critically acclaimed films that explore themes of poverty, inequality, and social justice, such as "I, Daniel Blake", "The Wind That Shakes the Barley", and "Riff-Raff".
Ken Roht is a American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on experimental and avant-garde films, including the critically acclaimed "The Neon Man and Me" (1987) and "The Last of the Fast Women" (1998).
Ken Scott is a Canadian film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the comedy films "The 40-Year-Old Virgin", "Knocked Up", "Superbad", and "This Is the End", as well as the comedy-horror film "Stuber".
Ken Shapiro is an American film director, writer, and producer, best known for directing the 1985 comedy film "Brewster's Millions" starring Richard Pryor and John Candy.
Kenneth Branagh is a renowned Irish actor, director, and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "Henry V", "Much Ado About Nothing", and the "Thor" franchise, as well as his adaptations of Agatha Christie's works, including "Murder on the Orient Express" and "Death on the Nile".
Kenneth Johnson is a renowned American film and television director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 1980s sci-fi series "V" and "The Bionic Woman".
Kenneth Lonergan is an American playwright, screenwriter, and film director, best known for his work on films such as "You Can Count on Me", "Margaret", and "Manchester by the Sea", which earned him an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.
Kenny Ortega is a renowned American film and television director, producer, and choreographer, best known for his work on iconic Disney movies and TV shows such as "High School Musical", "Hocus Pocus", and "The Cheetah Girls".
Kent Alterman is an American film and television producer, best known for being the President of Comedy Central and the President of Original Programming and Animation for Paramount Network and TV Land, and has been involved in the production of numerous successful TV shows and movies, including "South Park", "Broad City", and "The Other Guys".
Kerry Conran is a film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2004 film "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow", a science fiction adventure film that pays homage to the serials of the 1930s and 1940s.
Kevin Allen is a Welsh film director, writer, and actor, best known for directing the 1994 comedy-horror film "Tales of the Third Dimension" and the 1997 film "Stella Does Tricks".
Kevin Bray is a film director and stunt coordinator, known for his work on action-packed movies such as "Romeo Must Die", "Bulletproof", and "Exit Wounds", often collaborating with actors like Jet Li and Steven Seagal.
Kevin Brodie is a former American professional soccer player who played as a midfielder for the US national team and was a key player in the 1994 FIFA World Cup.
Kevin Carraway is a former American football safety who played in the National Football League (NFL) for the Carolina Panthers and Denver Broncos, and was a member of the Panthers' 2015 NFC South division-winning team.

Kevin Donovan is a fictional character and the main protagonist in the 1985 film "Back to the Future" played by Michael J. Fox, who travels back in time to November 5, 1955, and must ensure that his parents fall in love in order to secure his own existence.
Kevin Hamedani is an Iranian-American filmmaker and writer, best known for his work on the 2007 film "The Brothers Solomon", a comedy about two socially awkward brothers searching for love.
Kevin Hooks is an American actor and director, best known for his roles in the 1970s and 1980s, including the title character in the 1979 film "The Facts of Life" and as a regular cast member on the TV series "The White Shadow".

Kevin Reynolds is a British film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the 1988 film "The Field" starring Richard Harris and Sean Bean, as well as the 1997 film "The Saint" starring Val Kilmer.
Kevin Rodney Sullivan is an American film director, known for directing films such as "The Parent Trap" (1998), "Hollow Man" (2000), and "Madea's Family Reunion" (2006).
Kevin Smith is a renowned American filmmaker, actor, and comedian, best known for creating the View Askewniverse, a fictional universe that includes films such as "Clerks", "Mallrats", "Chasing Amy", and "Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back", among others.
Kevin Spacey is a renowned American actor, director, and producer who has won numerous awards, including an Academy Award, a Golden Globe Award, and multiple Tony Awards, and is known for his iconic roles in films like "The Usual Suspects", "American Beauty", and "House of Cards".
Kevin Tancharoen is a Filipino-American film and television director, best known for directing the 2010 musical comedy film "Mortal Kombat: Rebirth" and the web series "Mortal Kombat: Legacy", a prequel to the popular video game franchise.

Lance Rivera is a character from the 2002 film "Spider-Man" played by actor Joe Viterelli, who is a friend of Peter Parker's and helps him to develop his Spider-Man persona.

Lynne Ramsay is a Scottish film director, screenwriter, and producer known for her critically acclaimed and often award-winning films such as "Ratcatcher", "Morvern Callar", "We Need to Talk About Kevin", and "You Were Never Really Here", which have garnered her numerous accolades including the Grand Prix at the 2011 Cannes Film Festival and the Best Screenplay award at the 2017 Cannes Film Festival.

Mabrouk El Mechri is a Tunisian film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the 2008 film "JCVD" starring Jean-Claude Van Damme, which premiered at the Cannes Film Festival.
Maggie Carey is an American actress and writer, best known for creating and starring in the MTV comedy series "No Easy Days" and for being the ex-wife of actor Seth Rogen.

Majid Majidi is a renowned Iranian film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his poignant and visually stunning films such as "Children of Heaven", "Baran", and "The Color of Paradise", which have garnered international acclaim and numerous awards.
Malcolm D. Lee is a American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the films "The Best Man" (1999), "The Best Man Holiday" (2013), and "Girls Trip" (2017), and has also worked on films such as "Undercover Brother" (2002) and "Welcome Home Roscoe Jenkins" (2008).
Malcolm Goodwin is an American actor, best known for his role as Detective Steve Billings in the TNT drama series "iZombie" and as Detective August "Augie" Landi in the TV series "Breakout Kings".
Mamoru Hosoda is a renowned Japanese film director, known for his imaginative and emotionally charged animated films such as "The Girl Who Leapt Through Time", "Summer Wars", "Wolf Children", "The Boy and the Beast", and "Mirai", which often explore themes of childhood, identity, and human connection.
Marc Abraham is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the films "Deep Impact" (1998), "Spy Game" (2001), and "Flash of Genius" (2008).
Marc Bennett is a British actor, best known for his roles in films such as "The Fifth Element" (1997), "Entrapment" (1999), and "The Bourne Ultimatum" (2007).
Marc F. Adler is a film editor and producer who has worked on several notable films, including the Academy Award-winning documentary "The Cove" and the critically acclaimed drama "The Way Back".
Marc Forby is a film editor and cinematographer, best known for his work on the 2014 film "The Grand Budapest Hotel" directed by Wes Anderson, for which he received an Academy Award nomination for Best Film Editing.
Marc Forster is a Swiss film director, producer, and screenwriter known for directing films such as "Monster's Ball", "Finding Neverland", "Quantum of Solace", and "World War Z", among others.
Marc Lawrence is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on the popular comedy films "Miss Congeniality" (2000), "Miss Congeniality 2: Armed and Fabulous" (2005), and "Two Weeks Notice" (2002), starring Sandra Bullock and Hugh Grant.
Marc Levin is a film director and producer, known for his work on documentaries such as "The Other F Word" and "White Boy", as well as his TV series "The Wire" and "Oz", which he co-created with Robert F. Colesberry.
Marc Webb is a American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the romantic comedy "500 Days of Summer" and the "The Amazing Spider-Man" duology.
Marcio Garcia is a Brazilian film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2019 film "The Dead and the Others", a critically acclaimed adaptation of the novel by Nuno Ramos.
Marco Kreuzpaintner is a German film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2006 film "Sophie Scholl: The Final Days", a biographical drama about the life of Sophie Scholl, a German student who was executed for her involvement in the White Rose resistance movement during World War II.
Marco Schnabel is a German film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the animated film "Corpse Bride" (2005) and "Coraline" (2009), both of which were stop-motion animated and produced by Tim Burton.
Marcos Siega is a Chilean film director and screenwriter, known for his work on films such as "Wicker Park", "Dexter", and "The Vampire Diaries", as well as television series like "Pretty Little Liars" and "The Originals".
Marcus Dunstan is a American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the Saw franchise, particularly the seventh and eighth installments, as well as the Feast trilogy and The Collector.
Marcus Raboy is a renowned American film and television director, known for his work on numerous TV shows and movies, including the popular sitcom "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" and the comedy film "The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle".
Maria Maggenti is an American screenwriter and director, best known for writing and directing the 1998 romantic comedy-drama film "P.S. Your Cat Is Dead!", which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival and received critical acclaim.
Marianna Palka is a Polish-American actress, writer, and director, best known for her roles in films such as "Hear No Evil" and "G.B.F.", as well as her work on the TV series "Baskets" and "The Mick".
Marielle Heller is an American film director, screenwriter, and actress known for her work on films such as "The Diary of a Teenage Girl", "The Big Sick", and "Can You Ever Forgive Me?", which earned her Academy Award nominations for Best Director and Best Adapted Screenplay.
Mariette Monpierre is a 1988 French drama film directed by Ester Omry, which tells the story of a young woman's journey to discover her identity and find her place in the world after being abandoned by her mother at a young age.
Mario Van Peebles is an American actor, director, and producer, best known for his roles in films such as "New Jack City", "Alien Apocalypse", and "Panther", as well as his work on the TV series "Ali" and "Damages".
Mark A.Z. Dippé is an American film director, best known for directing the 1998 animated film "Blade" and the 2003 film "Santa Claus".
Mark Andrews is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the Academy Award-winning animated film "The Little Mermaid" (1989) and the fantasy adventure film "Dragonheart" (1996).
Mark Brown is a film director and producer, best known for directing the 1994 film "Blank Check" and the 2003 film "Kimberly".
Mark Christopher is a film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 1997 film "Party Monster", a biographical drama about the life of Michael Alig, a notorious club promoter and murderer, and for his uncredited rewrites on the 1996 film "54", a drama about the iconic Studio 54 nightclub.
Mark Dindal is an American film director, best known for directing the Disney animated films "Chicken Little" (2005) and "Bolt" (2008).
Mark Griffiths is a British psychologist and expert on addiction, who has written extensively on the topic of video game addiction and has been involved in the development of the concept of "Internet Addiction Disorder".
Mark Helfrich is a former American football coach who served as the head coach of the Oregon Ducks football team from 2013 to 2016, leading the team to a national championship appearance in 2014.
Mark Herman is a British film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the critically acclaimed films "Little Voice" (1998), "This Boy's Life" (1993), and "The Full Monty" (1997), which won the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.
Mark Illsley is a British film producer and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 1997 film "The Sweet Hereafter", which was nominated for several Academy Awards, including Best Original Screenplay.
Mark L. Lester is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the iconic action films "Commando" (1985) and "Showdown in Little Tokyo" (1991), as well as the sci-fi thriller "Firestarter" (1984).
Mark Mylod is a Northern Irish film and television director, best known for his work on the HBO comedy series "Succession" and the TV show "Shameless", as well as films like "The Guard" and "Pilgrim".
Mark Neveldine is a American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the Crank franchise, Gamer, and the action-packed films that often feature fast-paced editing and a blend of action, comedy, and drama.
Mark Osborne is a American film director, animator, and screenwriter, best known for directing the animated films "Kung Fu Panda" (2008) and "The Little Prince" (2015), which is an adaptation of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's classic novella.
Mark Pellington is a film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his work on films such as "Arlington Road", "The Mothman Prophecies", and "Ulee's Gold", as well as music videos for artists like Pearl Jam and Foo Fighters.
Mark Piznarski is a television director and producer, known for his work on popular TV shows such as "Gilmore Girls", "Veronica Mars", "Gossip Girl", and "Psych", among others.
Mark Romanek is a renowned American music video director and film director, known for his work on iconic music videos for artists such as Madonna, Nine Inch Nails, and Jay-Z, as well as his feature film debut "One Hour Photo" starring Robin Williams.
Mark Rosman is a film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1984 romantic comedy film "The House on Carroll Street" starring Kelly McGillis and Jeff Daniels.
Mark Rydell is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his work on iconic films such as "The Rose" (1979), "The Cowboys" (1972), and "On Golden Pond" (1981), which earned him Academy Award nominations for Best Director and Best Picture.
Mark Sandrich was an American film director, best known for directing the classic romantic comedies "The Philadelphia Story" (1940) and "Holiday" (1938), both starring Cary Grant and Katharine Hepburn.
Mark Steven Johnson is a film director, screenwriter, and producer, known for directing movies such as "Daredevil" (2003), "Elektra" (2005), and "Ghost Rider" (2007), as well as writing screenplays for films like "Killing Mrs. Tingle" (1999) and "Just Married" (2003).

Mark Young is a film composer who has worked on numerous movies and TV shows, including the scores for films like "The Craft", "Disturbing Behavior", and "The Skulls".

Martin Ritt was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his socially conscious and often critically acclaimed films such as "Norma Rae", "Sounder", and "The Front", which tackled issues like labor rights, racial inequality, and the Red Scare.
Martin Scorsese is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his gritty and intense films that often explore themes of redemption, violence, and the human condition, such as "Taxi Driver", "Raging Bull", "Goodfellas", and "The Departed".
Martyn Pick is a British film and television stunt coordinator, stunt double, and stunt arranger, known for his work on various productions including the Harry Potter franchise, Game of Thrones, and The Dark Knight trilogy.
Mary Harron is a Canadian film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for her adaptations of Bret Easton Ellis' novels, including "American Psycho" (2000) and "The Informers" (2008).

Matt Birch is a fictional character from the 1994 film "The Crow: City of Angels", played by Vincent Perez, who is the son of Eric Draven, the main character from the original 1994 film "The Crow".

Melvin Van Peebles was a pioneering African American filmmaker, actor, and musician who wrote, directed, and starred in the 1971 film "Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song", which was a groundbreaking work of independent cinema that helped to launch the Blaxploitation genre and paved the way for future generations of black filmmakers.

Michael Winner was a British film director, producer, and photographer, best known for directing the Death Wish series starring Charles Bronson, as well as films like The Mechanic and The Sentinel.
Michael Winnick is a Canadian film composer and music producer, known for his work on various films and television shows, including the horror movie "The Rite" (2011) and the TV series "The Haunting of Bly Manor" (2020).
Michael Winterbottom is a British film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his diverse and eclectic filmography, which includes critically acclaimed dramas such as "Tristram Shandy: A Cock and Bull Story", "24 Hour Party People", and "The Road to Guantanamo", as well as documentaries like "The Trip" and "The Shock Doctrine".
Michel Gondry is a French film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his unique visual style and imaginative storytelling, having directed films such as "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind", "The Science of Sleep", and "The Green Hornet".
Michel Hazanavicius is a French film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his critically acclaimed and award-winning films such as "The Artist" (2011), "OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies" (2005), and "The Search" (2014).
Michel Leclerc is a French film director and screenwriter, best known for his critically acclaimed films such as "The French Kissers" (2005), "The Players" (2009), and "The Best Years of a Life" (2019), which explore themes of love, relationships, and social issues in contemporary France.
Mick Jackson is a British film director, best known for directing the 1986 film "Tequila Sunrise" starring Mel Gibson, Michelle Pfeiffer, and Kurt Russell, as well as the 1991 film "True Colors" starring John Cusack and Stephen Mailer.
Mickey Liddell is a film producer and the founder of LD Entertainment, known for producing films such as "A Quiet Place", "The Grey", and "Rampart", and has been nominated for several awards including the Academy Award for Best Picture.
Miguel Arteta is a Venezuelan-American film director, known for his work on films such as "Chuck & Buck", "The Good Girl", "Youth in Revolt", and "Beatriz at Dinner", often exploring themes of human relationships, identity, and social commentary.
Miguel Sapochnik is a Chilean-American film and television director, best known for his work on Game of Thrones, where he directed several critically acclaimed episodes, including "Hardhome" and "Battle of the Bastards", and has also directed episodes of House of the Dragon and Vikings.
Mikael Håfström is a Swedish film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the psychological thriller "The Devil's Backbone" (2001) and the drama "81st Street" (2008).
Mikael Salomon is a Danish film director and cinematographer, known for his work on films such as "Revenge" (1990), "Steel Magnolias" (1989), and "Deep Impact" (1998), as well as television series like "Band of Brothers" (2001) and "The Pacific" (2010).
Mike Barker is an American film and television director, best known for his work on the animated TV series "Family Guy" and "American Dad!", as well as directing several episodes of the popular TV show "Buffy the Vampire Slayer".
Mike Bigelow is a fictional character and the main antagonist in the 1995 film "Tall Tale", played by Dan Aykroyd, who is a ruthless and cunning railroad tycoon seeking to buy out the land of Pecos Bill's family.
Mike Binder is a American actor, writer, and director, best known for his work on films such as "The Square" (1998), "Black and White" (1999), and "Reign Over Me" (2007), which often explore themes of family, relationships, and social issues.
Mike Cahill is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the critically acclaimed films "Another Earth" (2011) and "I Origins" (2014), which explore themes of science fiction, philosophy, and human connection.
Mike Disa is an American animator, director, and writer, best known for his work on animated films and television shows, including "The Powerpuff Girls", "Rocko's Modern Life", and "The Grim Adventures of Billy and Mandy".
Mike Figgis is a British film director, screenwriter, and composer, best known for his work on the films "Leaving Las Vegas" (1995), "The Browning Version" (1994), and "Time Code" (2000), which was shot in real-time and presented in four simultaneous screens.
Mike Flanagan is a renowned American filmmaker and screenwriter, best known for his work on horror movies such as "The Haunting of Hill House", "Doctor Sleep", and "Gerald's Game", which have received widespread critical acclaim for their atmospheric tension, complex characters, and thought-provoking themes.
Mike Gabriel is a renowned American animator, director, and producer who has worked on several iconic Disney films, including "The Little Mermaid", "Aladdin", and "Pocahontas", and is known for his unique storytelling style and memorable characters.
Mike Hodges is a British film director, best known for directing the 1971 film "Get Carter", a gritty and influential British gangster movie starring Michael Caine.
Mike Judge is a renowned American animator, writer, director, and producer, best known for creating the iconic adult animated series "Beavis and Butt-Head" and directing films like "Office Space" and "Idiocracy".
Mike Leigh is a renowned British film director, screenwriter, and playwright known for his critically acclaimed and often improvisation-based films that explore the complexities of human relationships, such as "Secrets & Lies", "Topsy-Turvy", and "Vera Drake".
Mike Marvin is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the 1985 cult classic film "Summer Rental" starring John Candy and Rip Torn.
Mike McCoy is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the action-comedy films "The Expendables" (2010), "The Expendables 2" (2012), and "The Expendables 3" (2014), as well as the TV series "Six" (2017-2018).
Mike Mills is a American film director, screenwriter, and animator, known for his critically acclaimed films such as "Beginners", "20th Century Women", and "Five Feet Apart", which often explore themes of family, identity, and human relationships.
Mike Mitchell is a American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for directing films such as "Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo", "The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause", "Tropic Thunder", and "Sausage Party".
Mike Nawrocki is a writer, director, and actor who has worked on several VeggieTales movies, including "Jonah: A VeggieTales Movie" and "The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie", and is also the voice of many characters in the franchise.
Mike Newell is a British film director, known for directing films such as "Four Weddings and a Funeral", "Donnie Brasco", "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", and "Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time".
Mike Nichols was a renowned American film and theater director, producer, and comedian, best known for his work on films such as "The Graduate", "Catch-22", "Silkwood", and "Angels in America", as well as his long-running comedy duo with Elaine May and his work on Broadway, earning him numerous awards and accolades throughout his career.
Mike van Diem is a Dutch film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his Academy Award-winning film "Charleston" (1999), a drama about a young man's journey to become a boxer in 1930s Amsterdam.
Mikel Rueda is a Spanish film director and screenwriter, known for his work on films such as "The Sleeping Voice" and "The Plague" which explore themes of social justice, politics, and human relationships.
Milos Forman was a renowned Czech-American film director, best known for his work on iconic films such as "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" and "Amadeus", which earned him multiple Academy Awards and cemented his reputation as a master of cinematic storytelling.
Mimi Leder is a renowned American film and television director, known for her work on films such as "Pay It Forward", "The Peacemaker", and "Deep Impact", as well as TV shows like "ER" and "On the Basis of Sex".
Mira Nair is a renowned Indian film director, producer, and screenwriter known for her critically acclaimed films such as "Salaam Bombay!" (1988), "Mississippi Masala" (1991), "Monsoon Wedding" (2001), and "The Namesake" (2006), which have explored themes of identity, culture, and social issues in Indian society.

Mitch Davis is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2004 family drama film "The Sandlot 2" and the 2011 drama film "The Other Side of Heaven".
Mitchell Altieri is a film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the horror films "The Hamiltons" (2006), "The Dead Ones" (2007), and "The Night Watchmen" (2017), which often explore themes of family trauma and the supernatural.
Mitchell Lichtenstein is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his 2006 film "Teeth", a dark comedy-horror film that premiered at the Sundance Film Festival and received critical acclaim.
Mona Fastvold is a Norwegian film director and screenwriter, known for her work on films such as "The Sleepwalker" (2014) and "The World to Come" (2020), which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival.
Monte Hellman is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on cult classics such as "Beast from Haunted Cave" (1959), "The Terror" (1963), and "Two-Lane Blacktop" (1971), which have gained a significant following over the years for their unique blend of style, atmosphere, and existential themes.
Mora Stephens is an American screenwriter and producer, best known for co-writing and producing the 2001 film "Wicked Pictures" and the 2018 film "Painkillers", which she also directed.
Morgan Freeman is a renowned American actor, director, and narrator who has appeared in a wide range of films, including "The Shawshank Redemption", "Million Dollar Baby", "March of the Penguins", and "The Dark Knight" trilogy, among many others.
Morgan Spurlock is a documentary filmmaker and television producer, best known for his 2004 film "Super Size Me", where he gained significant attention for losing 24.5 pounds and experiencing health problems after eating only McDonald's food for 30 days.
Mort Nathan is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2004 comedy film "Dirty Love" starring Jennifer Lopez and Matthew McConaughey.
Morten Tyldum is a Norwegian film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on films such as "Headhunters" and "The Imitation Game", which earned him an Academy Award nomination for Best Director.
Moustapha Akkad was a Syrian filmmaker and producer, best known for directing the 1976 film "The Message", a biographical epic about the life of the Prophet Muhammad, and also for producing the 1980 film "Saladin", a historical epic about the life of the Muslim leader Saladin.

Måns Mårlind is a Swedish film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on horror films such as "Dead Man's Right Hand" and "Darkness" alongside Björn Stein.
Nadia Tass is an Australian film director and actress, best known for directing the 1986 comedy film "Malcolm" starring Colin Friels and Lindy Davies.
Nadine Labaki is a Lebanese film director, screenwriter, and actress known for her critically acclaimed films such as "Caramel" and "Capernaum", which have gained international recognition and have been nominated for several awards, including the Academy Awards.
Nae Caranfil is a Romanian film director and screenwriter, best known for his 2007 film "The Paper Will Be Blue", a critically acclaimed drama that explores the events of the Romanian Revolution of 1989.

Neil Marshall is a British film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his work on horror and action films, including "Dog Soldiers", "The Descent", and "Doomsday", which have gained a cult following and critical acclaim for their intense action sequences, strong female leads, and atmospheric tension.
Neill Blomkamp is a South African film director, producer, and visual effects artist, best known for his work on sci-fi films such as District 9, Elysium, and Chappie, which often explore themes of xenophobia, class struggle, and humanity.

Nicholas Fackler is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his 2015 film "The Yellow Birds", an adaptation of Kevin Powers' novel of the same name, which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival and received critical acclaim.

Nickolas Perry is a fictional character from the 2019 American psychological thriller film "Us", played by Winston Duke, who is a loving father and husband whose family is attacked by their doppelgängers.

Oliver Blackburn is a British film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2009 film "It's All Gone Pete Tong", a mockumentary about a DJ who loses his hearing, and the 2011 film "You Instead", a romantic comedy about two strangers who fall in love at a music festival.
Oliver Hirschbiegel is a German film director, best known for directing the biographical drama film "Downfall" (2004), which tells the story of the final days of Adolf Hitler and the collapse of the Third Reich.
Oliver Parker is a British film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on romantic comedies such as "An Ideal Husband" (1999), "The School of Rock" (2003), and "St Trinian's" (2007).

Ossie Davis was an American actor, singer, and director who was known for his powerful performances in films such as "Do the Right Thing" and "Buck and the Preacher", and was also a prominent figure in the Civil Rights Movement.

Patrick Read Johnson is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for writing the screenplay for the 1994 film "Space Jam" starring Michael Jordan and Looney Tunes characters.

Patty Jenkins is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the critically acclaimed and commercially successful films "Monster" (2003) and "Wonder Woman" (2017), which became the highest-grossing film directed by a woman at the time of its release.
Paul Abascal is a Spanish film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1997 film "The Craft" and the 2001 film "Don't Say a Word".

Paul Bunnell is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for creating the 1997 horror film "The Relic", which was based on the novel of the same name by Douglas Preston and Lincoln Child.

Paul Gross is a Canadian actor, writer, and director, best known for his work on the TV series "Due South" and the film "Men with Brooms", as well as his role as Major Margaret MacKenzie in the 2002 film "Passchendaele".

Paul Hunter was a British professional snooker player who won three World Snooker Championships and was known for his attacking style of play, earning him the nickname "The Magician" on the snooker circuit.
Paul King is a British film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2014 film "Paddington" and its 2017 sequel, as well as the 2017 film "Goodbye Christopher Robin", a biographical drama about the life of author A.A. Milne.
Paul Mazursky was a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and actor, known for his work on films such as "Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice", "An Unmarried Woman", and "Down and Out in Beverly Hills", which often explored themes of relationships, identity, and social commentary.
Paul McGuigan is a British film and television director, known for his work on films such as "Lucky Number Slevin", "The Ghost Writer", and "Victor Frankenstein", as well as TV shows like "Sherlock" and "Orphan Black".
Paul Michael Glaser is an American actor, director, and producer, best known for his role as Detective David Starsky in the 1970s TV series "Starsky & Hutch".
Paul Schrader is a renowned American screenwriter, film director, and critic, best known for his work on films such as "Taxi Driver" (1976), "Raging Bull" (1980), and "American Gigolo" (1980), and is often credited with developing the concept of the "transgressor" character in his screenplays.
Paul Thomas Anderson is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his distinctive and often unconventional storytelling style, having directed critically acclaimed films such as "Boogie Nights", "Magnolia", "There Will Be Blood", and "The Master", among others.

Ritesh Batra is an Indian film director and screenwriter, known for his critically acclaimed films such as "The Lunchbox" (2013), "The Sense of an Ending" (2017), and "Photograph" (2019), which have premiered at various international film festivals and received numerous awards and nominations.
Rob Bowman is a Canadian film and television director, best known for his work on the TV series "X-Files" and "Lost", as well as films like "Reign of Fire" and "Elektra".
Rob Cohen is a film director, producer, and screenwriter known for directing the Fast and the Furious franchise, as well as other notable films such as The Waterboy, xXx, and Dragonheart.
Rob Hawk is a fictional character and the main protagonist in the 2007 science fiction film "I Am Number Four", played by Alex Pettyfer, who is a young alien from the planet Lorien fighting to survive on Earth against the evil alien forces known as the Mogadorians.
Rob Letterman is a film director and screenwriter, known for directing movies such as "Monsters vs. Aliens", "Gulliver's Travels", and "Goosebumps", and writing screenplays for films like "Shark Tale" and "Hotel Transylvania".
Rob Marshall is a renowned American film director, producer, and choreographer, best known for his work on musical films such as "Chicago", "Nine", and "Into the Woods", as well as his adaptation of "Mary Poppins Returns".
Rob McKittrick is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the 2006 comedy film "Waiting" and its 2015 sequel "Waiting... for 'Superman'".
Rob Minkoff is a renowned American film director, best known for directing the beloved Disney animated films "The Lion King" (1994) and "Stuart Little" (1999), as well as the live-action/CGI remake of "The Lion King" (2019).
Rob Pritts is a film editor and cinematographer, known for his work on several notable films, including "The Blair Witch Project" and "The Last Broadcast", which are considered to be among the first found-footage horror movies.
Rob Reiner is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing iconic films such as "This Is Spinal Tap", "The Princess Bride", "Stand by Me", "When Harry Met Sally", and "A Few Good Men", among many others.
Rob Zombie is a musician, filmmaker, and screenwriter known for directing horror movies such as "House of 1000 Corpses", "The Devil's Rejects", "Halloween", and "31", as well as creating music with his band White Zombie and as a solo artist.
Robby Henson is an American film director, writer, and producer, best known for his work on the Christian drama films "The Visitation" and "The Encounter", as well as the faith-based film "The Gospel of John".
Robert Adetuyi is a Canadian screenwriter and producer, best known for his work on the Step Up film series, including Step Up 2: The Streets, Step Up 3D, and Step Up Revolution.
Robert Altman was a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his innovative and often unconventional filmmaking style, which has been celebrated for its complex characters, intricate plots, and exploration of themes such as politics, morality, and the human condition, as seen in his iconic films like "M*A*S*H", "Nashville", and "Short Cuts".
Robert B. Weide is an American film and television director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on the HBO series "Curb Your Enthusiasm" and the documentary "Lenny Bruce: Swear to Tell the Truth".
Robert Ben Garant is a American actor, writer, and producer, best known for co-creating and writing the TV shows "Reno 911!" and "Childrens Hospital", as well as writing and producing several films, including "The Rocker" and "The Pacifier".
Robert Bennett is a fictional character from the 1994 film "Forrest Gump", played by actor Tom Hanks, who is Forrest's friend and confidant.
Robert Butler is an American film and television director, best known for directing the 1977 film "Superman" and the 1978-1979 TV series "Superman: The TV Series", which starred Christopher Reeve as the iconic superhero.
Robert C. Cooper is a Canadian television writer, producer, and director, best known for his work on the Stargate franchise, including Stargate SG-1, Stargate Atlantis, and Stargate Universe.
Robert Cary is a film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2004 film "Spanglish" and the 2011 film "The Way, Way Back".
Robert D. Webb was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing over 40 films, including the classic Western "The Man from Laramie" (1955) and the war drama "The Bridges at Toko-Ri" (1955), starring William Holden and Mickey Rooney.
Robert Duvall is a renowned American actor, director, and producer who has appeared in over 120 films and television shows, including iconic roles in "The Godfather," "Apocalypse Now," "Tender Mercies," and "Tremors," and has won numerous awards for his performances, including an Academy Award for Best Actor.
Robert Fontaine is a fictional character and the main protagonist in the 2013 American thriller film "The Iceman", played by Michael Shannon, which is loosely based on the true story of Richard Kuklinski, a notorious contract killer and serial murderer.
Robert Harmon is a Canadian film director, best known for directing the 1987 thriller film "The Running Man" starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, as well as the 1994 film "Tales from the Darkside: The Movie" based on the popular TV series.
Robert Iscove is a Canadian film and television director, best known for directing the 1999 teen comedy film "She's All That" starring Freddie Prinze Jr. and Rachael Leigh Cook.
Robert Lee King is an American actor, best known for his role as the titular character in the 1998 horror film "Candyman", which was based on a short story by Clive Barker.
Robert Lorenz is a film director, producer, and editor, best known for directing the 2005 comedy film "Guess Who", as well as producing and editing several other films, including the "My Dog Skip" and "Mystery, Alaska" movies.
Robert Luketic is a film director and producer, known for directing movies such as "Legally Blonde", "21", and "The Ugly Truth", and has worked with actors like Reese Witherspoon, Jim Sturgess, and Katherine Heigl.

Robert Moresco is an American screenwriter, film director, and producer, best known for his work on films such as "Crash" (2004), "Traffic" (2000), and "Million Dollar Baby" (2004), for which he won an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.
