Robert Redford is a renowned American actor, director, and environmentalist, best known for his iconic roles in films such as "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid", "The Sting", and "All the President's Men", as well as his founding of the Sundance Film Festival.
Robert Rodriguez is a renowned American filmmaker, screenwriter, and musician, best known for his work on the "El Mariachi" trilogy, "Desperado", "From Dusk Till Dawn", and the "Spy Kids" franchise, among many other films that showcase his unique blend of action, comedy, and horror elements.
Robert Rossen was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the classic films "All the King's Men" (1949), "The Hustler" (1961), and "The Wild One" (1953), and was also a key figure in the Hollywood Blacklist during the Red Scare of the 1950s.
Robert Sarkies is a New Zealand film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 1999 film "Scarfies" and the 2002 film "Out of the Blue", which was based on the 1990 Aramoana massacre.
Robert Schwentke is a German film director and screenwriter, known for directing films such as "Flightplan", "The Time Traveler's Wife", and "R.I.P.D.", as well as episodes of TV shows like "The Sopranos" and "Six Feet Under".
Robert Stevenson was a renowned Scottish-American film director, best known for directing classic Disney movies such as "Treasure Island" (1950), "Old Yeller" (1957), and "Mary Poppins" (1964), which won five Academy Awards.
Robert Stromberg is a renowned American art director, production designer, and visual effects supervisor, best known for his work on films such as "Avatar", "Alice in Wonderland", and "Oz the Great and Powerful", earning him multiple Academy Award nominations and wins.
Robert Towne is a renowned American film director, writer, and producer, best known for his work on iconic films such as "Chinatown" (1974), "The Last Detail" (1973), and "Personal Best" (1982), earning him multiple Academy Award nominations and a reputation for crafting complex, character-driven stories.

Robinson Devor is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the 2005 documentary film "Punks, Cha-Chas, and the Transgender Experience", which explores the lives of transgender individuals in the Seattle punk rock scene.

Rodman Flender is a British film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1995 horror film "Tales from the Hood" and the 1997 comedy film "The Faculty", which was written by Kevin Williamson and starred Elijah Wood and Josh Hartnett.

Roland Joffé is a British film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the Academy Award-winning film "The Killing Fields" (1984) and the epic historical drama "The Mission" (1986).
Roman Polanski is a Polish-French film director, producer, writer, and actor who is best known for directing the critically acclaimed films "Rosemary's Baby", "Chinatown", and "The Pianist", which won the Academy Award for Best Director in 2003.
Ron Clements is a renowned American film director and animator, best known for his work on Disney animated classics such as "The Little Mermaid", "Aladdin", "Hercules", and "Moana", and has been a key figure in the development of Disney's animated feature films for over three decades.

Shari Springer Berman is a film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for her work on films such as "American Splendor" (2003), "The Illusionist" (2006), and "Louie" (2010-2015), which earned her numerous awards and nominations, including an Academy Award nomination for Best Adapted Screenplay.
Sharon Greytak is a renowned film editor, best known for her work on the Academy Award-winning documentary "The Cove" (2009) and the critically acclaimed drama "The Way Way Back" (2013).
Sharon Maguire is a British film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2001 romantic comedy film "Bridget Jones's Diary" and its 2016 sequel "Bridget Jones's Baby".
Shawn Levy is a Canadian film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for directing popular movies such as "Night at the Museum", "Real Steel", "Date Night", and "This Is Where I Leave You", among others.
"Shekar" is a 2022 Indian Tamil-language psychological thriller film written and directed by Avani Srinivasan, starring Vijay Deverakonda and Rashmika Mandanna, which revolves around a man who is accused of murder and must prove his innocence.
Shekhar Kapur is a renowned Indian film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his critically acclaimed films such as "Bandit Queen", "Masoom", and "Elizabeth", which earned him international recognition and several awards, including the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival.
Sheldon Lettich is a American screenwriter, director, and producer, best known for writing and directing the 1992 action film "Universal Soldier" starring Jean-Claude Van Damme and Dolph Lundgren.
Sherman Alexie is a renowned American author, poet, and filmmaker of Native American descent, best known for his semi-autobiographical novel "The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian" and his critically acclaimed film "Smoke Signals", which was based on his short story collection "The Lone Ranger and Tonto Fistfight in Heaven".
Shimit Amin is an Indian film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the critically acclaimed films "Rockstar" (2011) and "Chak De India" (2007), which won several awards including the National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Hindi.
Shintaro Shimosawa is a Japanese film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the psychological thriller film "Before I Wake" (2016) and the horror film "Creepy" (2016), which received critical acclaim and commercial success in Japan.
Shona Auerbach is a Scottish film director and screenwriter, best known for her 2007 film "Arctic Tale", a documentary-style drama that follows the lives of two polar bear cubs and a walrus calf in the Arctic.
Shyam Madiraju is a film editor who has worked on several notable movies, including "Crazy Rich Asians", "To All the Boys I've Loved Before", and "The Kissing Booth", among others.
Siddharth Anand is a renowned Indian film director and screenwriter, best known for directing successful Bollywood films such as "Bang Bang!", "Salaam Namaste", and "War", which holds the record for the highest opening weekend in India.
Siddiq Barmak is an Afghan film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2003 film "Osama", which was the first feature film to be made in Afghanistan after the fall of the Taliban regime and won several international awards, including the Un Certain Regard prize at the 2003 Cannes Film Festival.
Sidney J. Furie is a Canadian film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1973 film "The Ipcress File" and the 1976 film "Superman IV: The Quest for Peace".
Sidney Lumet was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his gritty and realistic portrayals of urban life, social issues, and human drama, directing iconic films such as "12 Angry Men", "Dog Day Afternoon", and "Network".
Simeon Rice is a former American football defensive end who played in the National Football League (NFL) for 11 seasons, including stints with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Indianapolis Colts, and Detroit Lions, and was a key member of the Buccaneers' Super Bowl XXXVII championship team.
Simon Curtis is a British film and television director, best known for his work on films such as "My Week with Marilyn" and "Woman in Gold", as well as TV series like "Doctor Who" and "The Musketeers".
Simon Wells is a British film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2000 film "Atlantis: The Lost Empire" and the 2005 film "War of the Worlds", both of which were based on classic science fiction stories by Edgar Rice Burroughs and H.G. Wells, respectively.
Simon West is a British film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for directing blockbuster films such as "Con Air", "The General's Daughter", "Lara Croft: Tomb Raider", and "When a Stranger Calls", among others.
Simon Wincer is an Australian film and television director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing films such as "Quigley Down Under", "Lone Justice", and "Free Willy", as well as television shows like "Baa Baa Black Sheep" and "Vietnam War Story".
Sngmoo Lee is a South Korean film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2004 film "A Moment to Remember" and the 2010 film "My Dear Enemy".
Sofia Coppola is a renowned American film director, producer, and actress, known for her distinctive style and critically acclaimed films such as "Lost in Translation", "Marie Antoinette", and "The Beguiled", which often explore themes of identity, relationships, and the human condition.
Sol Tryon is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 2019 American drama film "The Farewell", directed by Lulu Wang, in which he is a young Chinese-American man who returns to China to say goodbye to his terminally ill grandmother without telling her the true reason for his visit.
Spencer Susser is an Australian film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the 2009 film "I Love You Man" and the 2011 film "Hesher", which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival.
Spike Jonze is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his unique and quirky storytelling style, which has been showcased in films such as "Being John Malkovich", "Adaptation", and "Her", earning him numerous awards and nominations, including an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay.
Spike Lee is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his provocative and socially conscious films such as "Do the Right Thing", "Malcolm X", and "25th Hour", which often explore themes of race, identity, and social justice.
Stanley Donen was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on iconic musicals such as "Singin' in the Rain" (1952), "Seven Brides for Seven Brothers" (1954), and "Charade" (1963), as well as his collaborations with Audrey Hepburn in "Funny Face" (1957) and "Charade".
Stanley Kramer was a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his socially conscious and thought-provoking films that tackled complex issues such as racism, war, and social inequality, including classics like "On the Waterfront", "The Defiant Ones", and "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner".
Stanley Kubrick was a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and photographer known for his visually stunning and thought-provoking films such as "2001: A Space Odyssey", "A Clockwork Orange", "The Shining", and "Full Metal Jacket", which explored themes of human nature, technology, and the human condition.
Stanley Tong is a Hong Kong film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the Jackie Chan films "Rumble in the Bronx" (1995), "Supercop" (1992), and "Rush Hour" (1998).
Stanton Barrett is an American stunt driver, stunt coordinator, and actor who has worked on numerous films and television shows, including the Fast and Furious franchise, The Dukes of Hazzard, and The Walking Dead.
Stefan C. Schaefer is a German-American film editor and sound designer, best known for his work on films such as "The Grand Budapest Hotel", "Moonrise Kingdom", and "The Darjeeling Limited", all directed by Wes Anderson.
Stefan Ruzowitzky is an Austrian film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the Academy Award-winning film "The Counterfeiters" (2007), a historical drama based on the true story of the largest counterfeiting operation in history, which took place in Nazi concentration camps during World War II.
Stefan Schwartz is a British film and television director, known for his work on shows such as "The O.C.", "Gossip Girl", and "The Vampire Diaries", as well as films like "The Guru" and "The Black Dahlia".
Stefen Fangmeier is a American film director, visual effects supervisor, and cinematographer, best known for his work on films such as "The Lost World: Jurassic Park", "Men in Black", and "War of the Worlds".
Stephan Elliott is an Australian film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the 1994 comedy film "The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert" and the 2018 comedy film "Swinging Safari".
Stephen Carpenter is an American musician, best known as the guitarist and founding member of the nu metal band Deftones, known for their unique blend of alternative metal, shoegaze, and dream pop sounds.
Stephen Chbosky is a American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for writing and directing the coming-of-age film "The Perks of Being a Wallflower" (2012) and directing the films "Rent" (2005) and "Beauty and the Beast" (2017).
Stephen Chow is a Hong Kong actor, filmmaker, and comedian known for his work in films such as "Shaolin Soccer", "Kung Fu Hustle", and "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon", which often blend martial arts, comedy, and fantasy elements.
Stephen Daldry is a British film and theatre director, known for his work on films such as "Billy Elliot", "The Hours", and "The Crown", as well as his long-running collaborations with the Royal Shakespeare Company and the National Theatre.
Stephen Frears is a British film director known for his work on a wide range of films, including "My Beautiful Laundrette", "The Grifters", "The Snapper", "Philomena", and "Victoria and Abdul", among many others.
Stephen Gaghan is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on films such as "Traffic" (2000), "Syriana" (2005), and "Gold" (2016), which have garnered critical acclaim and numerous awards.
Stephen Herek is a film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his work on movies such as "Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure" (1989), "The Grand Budapest Hotel" (2014), and "Mr. Holland's Opus" (1995), among others.
Stephen Hillenburg was an American animator, writer, director, and marine biologist best known for creating the beloved Nickelodeon animated television series "SpongeBob SquarePants" which premiered in 1999 and became a global phenomenon.
Stephen Hopkins is a British film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for directing films such as "A Nightmare on Elm Street 7: The Dream Child" (1989), "The Ghost and the Darkness" (1996), and "Blow" (2001).
Stephen J. Anderson is an American animator, director, and screenwriter, best known for his work on Disney animated films such as "Meet the Robinsons", "Winnie the Pooh", and "Wreck-It Ralph", and has also directed several short films and television episodes.
Stephen Kay is a British film director and screenwriter, known for his work on films such as "Bullet to the Head" (2012), "Drive Angry" (2011), and "The Mechanic" (2011), as well as television shows like "Dexter" and "Ray Donovan".
Stephen Milburn Anderson is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the films "Wrong Turn" (2003), "The Fog" (2005), and "Killers" (2010).
Stephen Norrington is a British film director, best known for directing the 1998 superhero horror film "Blade" and its 2002 sequel "Blade II", which helped to establish the modern comic book movie genre.
Stephen Sommers is a film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his work on action-adventure films such as "The Mummy" (1999), "Van Helsing" (2004), and "G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra" (2009).
Sterling Van Wagenen was an American film director, producer, and cinematographer who co-founded the Sundance Film Festival and was a key figure in the development of independent filmmaking in the United States.
Steve Antin is an American actor, screenwriter, and director, best known for his role as Zack in the 1987 film "The Bold and the Beautiful" and for writing and directing the 2011 film "Burlesque", starring Christina Aguilera and Cher.
Steve Bendelack is a British film and television director, best known for his work on the comedy series "The League of Gentlemen" and the horror film "Burke & Hare".
Steve Box is a British animator and director, best known for co-directing the animated films "Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit" and "Flushed Away" with Nick Park.
Steve Boyum is a film director and television director, known for his work on TV shows such as "Supernatural", "Smallville", and "Hawaii Five-0", as well as movies like "The Scorpion King" and "The Punisher".
Steve Buscemi is a renowned American actor, director, and producer, known for his distinctive voice and versatility in a wide range of film and television roles, including iconic performances in "Fargo", "The Big Lebowski", and "Boardwalk Empire".
Steve Carr is a British film director, best known for directing the comedy films "Whatever Happened to Harold Smith?" (1999), "Johnson's Lives in the Day" (2000), and "Jake in Progress" (2002-2003).
Steve Carver is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1985 action film "Big Trouble in Little China" starring Kurt Russell and Kim Cattrall.
Steve Hickner is an American film director and animator, best known for directing the animated films "The Prince of Egypt" (1998) and "Tarzan" (1999) for Walt Disney Feature Animation.
Steve James is a renowned American documentary filmmaker, best known for directing the critically acclaimed documentary "Hoop Dreams" (1994) and the "Life" documentary series, which includes films such as "The Interrupters" (2011) and "Abacus: Small Enough to Jail" (2016).
Steve Martino is an American film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the films "Love Don't Cost a Thing" (2003), "The Love Guru" (2008), and "Earth to Echo" (2014).
Steve McQueen was a legendary American actor and filmmaker who starred in iconic films such as "Bullitt", "The Great Escape", and "Papillon", and is often referred to as a "cool" and "tough" actor due to his rugged on-screen presence and memorable performances.
Steve Miner is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on the Friday the 13th franchise, including the first two films, as well as the Halloween sequels Halloween II and Halloween H20: 20 Years Later.
Steve Oedekerk is a comedian, actor, and filmmaker who is best known for creating the popular comedy films "The Nutty Professor" and "Ace Ventura: When Nature Calls", as well as creating and starring in the Nickelodeon sketch comedy show "All Growed Up".
Steve Pink is an American film director, writer, and actor, known for his work on films such as "High Fidelity", "Grosse Pointe Blank", and "Hot Tub Time Machine", and is often credited as a protégé of John Cusack, with whom he has collaborated on several projects.
Steve Rash is a American film director, producer, and editor, best known for directing the films "This Is Spinal Tap" (1984), "Teen Wolf" (1985), and "Can't Buy Me Love" (1987).
Steve Taylor is a British musician, singer-songwriter, and music video director, best known for his work in the 1980s and 1990s with his band Steve Taylor & the Perfect Foil, as well as his solo career and his work on music videos for other artists such as Michael W. Smith and Newsboys.
Steven Brill is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on comedy films such as "Billy Madison", "The Wedding Singer", and "Little Nicky", as well as his more recent projects like "Blended" and "Zoolander 2".
Steven E. de Souza is a Canadian film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the action-comedy films "Die Hard" (1988) and "The Running Man" (1987), as well as writing the screenplay for "Beverly Hills Cop II" (1987).
Steven Quale is an American film director and producer, best known for directing the horror films "Into the Blue" and "The Darkest Hour", as well as the documentary "Aliens of the Deep" with James Cameron.
Steven Seagal is a renowned American actor, producer, and martial artist, best known for his iconic action films such as "Under Siege", "Above the Law", and "Hard to Kill", which showcased his signature blend of martial arts skills and tough-guy persona.
Steven Shainberg is a film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2002 film "Secretary", a romantic drama starring James Spader and Maggie Gyllenhaal, which received critical acclaim and earned several award nominations.

Steven Spielberg is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter who has directed iconic movies such as "Jaws", "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial", "Jurassic Park", and "Indiana Jones" series, among many others, and has won numerous awards for his work, including three Academy Awards.

Stewart Raffill is a film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the cult classic films "Mac and Me" (1988) and "Dolphin Kick" (1990), as well as other films such as "The Ice Pirates" (1984) and "Heartbreak Hotel" (1988).
Stig Bergqvist is a Swedish film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 1991 film "The Slums", a critically acclaimed drama that explores the lives of marginalized youth in Stockholm's suburbs.
Stuart Baird is a British film editor and director, known for his work on films such as "The Long Good Friday", "Naked Gun 33 1/3: The Final Insult", and "X2: X-Men United", as well as directing films like "Executive Decision" and "U.S. Marshals".

Stuart Gordon is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on cult classic films such as "Re-Animator" (1985), "From Beyond" (1986), and "Space Truckers" (1996), often blending elements of horror, science fiction, and dark comedy.
Stéphane Aubier is a Belgian animator and director, best known for co-creating the stop-motion animated films "Ernest & Celestine" and "The Secret of Kells", which received critical acclaim and won numerous awards.
Sue Corcoran is a Canadian film and television producer, best known for her work on the popular TV series "Trailer Park Boys" and "Mr. D".
Susan Seidelman is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for her work on the iconic 1985 film "Desperately Seeking Susan", which launched the careers of Madonna and Rosanna Arquette, and explored themes of identity, relationships, and the search for meaning in the 1980s.
Susan Stroman is a renowned American director, choreographer, and producer, best known for her work on Broadway musicals such as "The Producers", "Contact", and "Young Frankenstein", as well as her television work on shows like "Everybody Loves Raymond" and "The Good Wife".
Susanna White is a fictional character in the 1997 film "Amistad", played by actress Anna Paquin, who is the wife of Joseph Cinqué, the leader of the African slaves who rise up against their Spanish captors on board the Amistad.
Susanne Bier is a Danish film director and screenwriter known for her critically acclaimed films such as "Open Hearts", "After the Wedding", "Things We Lost in the Fire", and "In a Better World", which won the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film in 2011.
Sydney Pollack was a renowned American film director, producer, and actor, known for his work on iconic films such as "Tootsie", "Out of Africa", "The Way We Were", and "Three Days of the Condor", among many others.
Sylvain Chomet is a French animator and film director, best known for his work on the animated films "The Triplets of Belleville" and "The Illusionist", which were both critically acclaimed and won numerous awards.
Sylvain White is a French film director, known for directing the 2007 film "Stomp the Yard" and the 2009 film "The Losers", as well as several episodes of the TV series "Stargate SG-1" and "Stargate Atlantis".
Sylvester Stallone is a renowned American actor, writer, and director, best known for creating and starring in the iconic Rocky and Rambo film franchises, which have become synonymous with his tough-guy persona and memorable performances.
Sylvio Tabet is a Lebanese-French screenwriter and film producer, best known for his work on the popular animated film series "Barbie" and "Care Bears", as well as the animated TV series "The Care Bears Family" and "Barbie: Life in the Dreamhouse".
Tadeo Garcia is a fictional character and the main protagonist in the 2006 American fantasy adventure film "The Prestige", played by Hugh Jackman, who is a rival magician to Angier (played by Christian Bale) in a competition of one-upmanship and deception.
Takao Okawara is a Japanese film director, best known for directing several Godzilla films, including "Godzilla vs. Mechagodzilla II" (1993), "Godzilla vs. SpaceGodzilla" (1994), and "Godzilla vs. Destoroyah" (1995).

Tamara Jenkins is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for her critically acclaimed films such as "Slums of Beverly Hills" (1998) and "Private Life" (2018), which explore themes of family, identity, and human relationships.
Tamra Davis is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1994 comedy film "Half Baked" starring Dave Chappelle and the 2001 comedy film "Crossroads" starring Britney Spears and Zoe Saldana.

Tara Subkoff is an American actress, director, and screenwriter, best known for her roles in films such as "The Love Song for Bobby Long" and "I'm Losing You", as well as her work on the TV series "The Nine" and "The Agency".
Tarsem Singh is a Indian-American film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his visually stunning and often surreal films such as "The Cell", "The Fall", and "Mirror Mirror", which showcase his unique storytelling style and attention to detail.
Tate Taylor is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the Academy Award-winning film "The Help" (2011) and the critically acclaimed drama "Get on Up" (2014).
Tay Garnett was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter who directed over 60 films during his career, including the classic 1939 film "AIR FORCE" starring John Garfield and directed the 1944 film "THE CROSSROADS OF SAN ANTONIO" starring Gene Tierney.

Ted Demme was an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the films "Blow" (2001), "Life" (1999), and "The Ref" (1994), as well as episodes of popular TV shows such as "The Sopranos" and "Everybody Loves Raymond".
Ted Kotcheff is a Canadian film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1982 film "First Blood" starring Sylvester Stallone, as well as other notable films such as "The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz" and "Uncommon Valor".
Ted Post was an American film and television director, best known for directing the 1975 film "The Deer Hunter" and the 1979 film "Magnum Force", as well as numerous episodes of popular TV shows such as "M*A*S*H" and "Hill Street Blues".
Teddy Chan is a Hong Kong film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for directing films such as "Heavenly Mission", "The Accidental Spy", and "New Police Story", and has worked with notable actors like Jackie Chan and Andy Lau.
Terence Davies is a British film director, screenwriter, and editor known for his critically acclaimed and highly personal films such as "Distant Voices, Still Lives" and "The House of Mirth", which often explore themes of memory, identity, and the human condition.
Terence Young was a British film director, producer, and screenwriter who is best known for directing the first three James Bond films, including "Dr. No", "From Russia with Love", and "Goldfinger", and was instrumental in establishing the tone and style of the franchise.
Terrence Malick is a renowned American film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his poetic and philosophical films that often explore themes of existence, nature, and human relationships, such as "Badlands", "Days of Heaven", "The Thin Red Line", "The New World", and "Tree of Life".
Terron R. Parsons is a film producer and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 1995 film "Friday" and its sequel "Next Friday", which starred Ice Cube and helped launch the careers of several young actors, including Mike Epps and Faizon Love.
Terry George is a Northern Irish film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the films "Hotel Rwanda" and "The Promise", which explore themes of human rights and genocide.
Terry Gilliam is a renowned British film director, screenwriter, and animator, best known for his surreal and often fantastical films such as "Brazil", "12 Monkeys", and "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas", which have garnered critical acclaim and cult followings worldwide.
Terry Zwigoff is a American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his dark comedies and dramas such as "Bad Santa" (2003), "Ghost World" (2001), and "What's Eating Gilbert Grape" (1993).

Theodore Melfi is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing and co-writing the films "St. Vincent" (2014), "Susan Cooper" (2015), and "The Snowman" (2017), as well as co-writing the screenplay for the biographical drama "Hidden Figures" (2016).
Theodore Witcher is a 1999 American drama film directed by Bill Duke, starring Ving Rhames and Halle Berry, which tells the story of a former convict who returns to his hometown to find his 12-year-old daughter being raised by his ex-wife and her abusive boyfriend.
Thomas Bezucha is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on films such as "Big Eden" (2000), "The Family Stone" (2005), and "The Family Tree" (2011).
Thomas Carter is a film director and producer, known for directing several successful movies, including "Save the Last Dance", "Coach Carter", and "Drillbit Taylor", among others.
Thomas L. Phillips was a renowned film editor who worked on several notable movies, including the 1975 film "Jaws" and the 1980 film "Raging Bull", both directed by Steven Spielberg and Martin Scorsese respectively.
Thomas Lilti is a French film director, screenwriter, and actor, best known for his work on the 2019 film "The Eddy", a Netflix original series created by Lilti and Jack Thorne, which explores the world of jazz and the struggles of its characters.
Thomas Vinterberg is a Danish film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his work on the Dogme 95 movement and films such as "The Celebration" and "The Hunt".

Tim Boxell is a British film editor, known for his work on films such as "The Full Monty" and "Billy Elliot", and has received several award nominations for his contributions to the film industry.
Tim Burton is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his dark, gothic, and quirky style, having directed iconic films such as "Beetlejuice", "Edward Scissorhands", "The Nightmare Before Christmas", and "Sleepy Hollow", among many others.
Tim Chambers is a British actor, best known for his roles in the 1990s British comedy-drama film "Truly, Madly, Deeply" and the 1994 film "Stones of Summer".
Tim Fywell is a British film and television director, known for his work on films such as "Bridget Jones's Diary" and "The Holiday", as well as TV shows like "Casualty" and "Midsomer Murders".

Tim Hill is a American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing family-friendly films such as "Alvin and the Chipmunks", "Hop", and "Sonic the Hedgehog".
Tim Hunter is a film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the 1985 coming-of-age film "River's Edge" and the 1986 film "Made in U.S.A.", as well as episodes of popular TV shows such as "Twin Peaks" and "Supernatural".
Tim Johnson is an American film director and producer, best known for directing animated films such as "Over the Hedge", "Bolt", "Home", and "Abominable", and has also worked on various other animated and live-action projects throughout his career.
Tim McCanlies is a screenwriter and film director, best known for writing the screenplay for the 1997 film "A Simple Plan" and directing the 2001 film "Dinosaur".
Tim Miller is a Canadian film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2016 film Deadpool, which was a critical and commercial success and helped establish the X-Men franchise's R-rated direction.
Tim Robbins is a renowned American actor, known for his iconic roles in films such as "The Shawshank Redemption", "Mystic River", and "Bull Durham", earning him numerous award nominations and wins, including an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor.
Tim Story is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the popular films "Barbershop", "Barbershop 2: Back in Business", "Stomp the Yard", "Fantastic Four", and "Ride Along", among others.
Timothy Björklund is a Swedish-American animator, director, and producer who has worked on several animated films and TV shows, including "The Rugrats Movie", "The Wild Thornberrys Movie", and "The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie".
Timothy Hines is a British film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for directing the 2013 film "Hansel & Gretel Get Baked" and the 2015 film "Hansel & Gretel: Warriors of Witchcraft", both of which are modern retellings of the classic Brothers Grimm fairy tale.

Timur Bekmambetov is a Kazakhstani film director, producer, and screenwriter, known for his work on films such as "Night Watch", "Day Watch", "Wanted", and "Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter".
Tina Gordon Chism is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the 2019 comedy film "Little" starring Marsai Martin, Regina Hall, and Issa Rae.
Tobe Hooper is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on horror classics such as "The Texas Chain Saw Massacre" (1974), "Eaten Alive" (1977), and "Poltergeist" (1982), which he co-directed with Steven Spielberg.
Todd Field is a American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for his critically acclaimed films "In the Bedroom" (2001), "Little Children" (2006), and "Waves" (2019), which have earned him numerous awards and nominations, including Academy Award nominations for Best Director and Best Original Screenplay.
Todd Graff is an American actor, singer, and director, best known for his work on the musical films "Camp" (2003) and "Camp Rock" (2008), as well as the TV series "Fame" (2009).
Todd Haynes is a critically acclaimed American independent film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his visually stunning and emotionally charged films such as "Carol", "Far from Heaven", and "Velvet Goldmine", which often explore themes of identity, sexuality, and social politics.
Todd Phillips is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter, best known for his work on comedy films such as "Old School", "The Hangover" trilogy, and "Joker", which earned him critical acclaim and numerous awards, including the Academy Award for Best Director.
Todd Solondz is a American independent film director, writer, and producer known for his darkly comedic and often controversial films that explore themes of family dysfunction, trauma, and social awkwardness, including "Welcome to the Dollhouse", "Happiness", and "Palindromes".
Todd Strauss-Schulson is an American film director, screenwriter, and producer, best known for directing the 2011 comedy film "A Very Harold & Kumar Christmas" and the 2018 horror comedy film "Tragedy Girls".
Tom Brady is a legendary American football quarterback who has won seven Super Bowl rings and four Super Bowl MVP awards throughout his career with the New England Patriots and Tampa Bay Buccaneers.
Tom Dey is an American film director and screenwriter, best known for directing the films "Mystery, Alaska" (1999), "Witless Protection" (2008), and "Take the Lead" (2006), which starred Antonio Banderas.

Tom Elkins is a fictional character and the protagonist of the 2011 horror film "The Howling: Reborn", played by Landon Liboiron, who is a teenager who discovers he is the son of a werewolf and must learn to control his newfound powers.
Tom Ford is a renowned American fashion designer, film director, and screenwriter, best known for his work as the creative director of Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent, as well as directing and writing the Academy Award-winning film "A Single Man" and the critically acclaimed "Nocturnal Animals".
Tom Gormican is a film director, writer, and producer, best known for directing the 2022 comedy film "Barb and Star Go to Vista Del Mar" starring Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo, as well as the 2019 comedy film "Freaky Friday" starring Lindsay Lohan and Jamie Lee Curtis.

Tony Richardson was a British film and theatre director, known for his work on films such as "Tom Jones" (1963), "The Loved One" (1965), and "Alfie" (1966), and was a key figure in the British New Wave movement of the 1960s.

Vic Sarin is a Canadian cinematographer and director, known for his work on films such as "Eve and the Fire Horse", "My Name is Tanino", and "Helen", as well as being the first cinematographer to win an Academy Award for Best Cinematography in a Documentary Feature for "A Different Kind of Christmas".

Wolfgang Becker is a German film director, best known for his 2003 film "Good Bye Lenin!", a comedy-drama that tells the story of a young man who tries to recreate the East German state's propaganda and ideology for his mother, who has just woken up from a coma and thinks it's still the 1980s.

Christopher Schmidt is a character played by actor Bill Hader in the 2013 comedy film "Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2", where he is a former child star turned eccentric scientist.

Drake Bell is an American actor, musician, and singer-songwriter, best known for his role as Drake Parker on the Nickelodeon sitcom "Drake & Josh" and for his music career as a solo artist and as part of the duo Drake Bell and Josh Peck.
Drea de Matteo is an American actress, best known for her roles as Adriana La Cerva on the HBO drama series "The Sopranos" and as Joey Tribbiani's sister Gina on the NBC sitcom "Joey".
Dreama Walker is an American actress, best known for her roles as Zoe Barnes in the Netflix series "House of Cards" and as Becca in the ABC comedy series "Don't Trust the B---- in Apartment 23".
Dree Hemingway is an American actress and model, best known for her roles in films such as "Grandma" and "Love & Mercy", as well as being the great-granddaughter of Ernest Hemingway.
Drew Carey is an American actor, comedian, and game show host, best known for hosting the popular game show "The Price is Right" since 2007 and starring in the sitcom "The Drew Carey Show" from 1995 to 2004.

Dustin Fitzsimons is a fictional character from the 1994 film "The Paper" played by actor Liev Schreiber, who is a young journalist working for the New York City newspaper "The Daily News".

Eric Cantona is a former French professional footballer who played for clubs like Manchester United, Leeds United, and Marseille, and is also known for his acting career, starring in films like "Elizabeth" and "Looking for Victoria".
Eric Dane is an American actor, best known for his roles as Dr. Mark "McSteamy" Sloan on the medical drama television series "Grey's Anatomy" and as Charlie Harper on the sitcom "Two and a Half Men".
Eric Elmosnino is a French actor, best known for his portrayal of Serge Gainsbourg in the 2009 biographical film "Gainsbourg: A Heroic Life", for which he received critical acclaim and won several awards.
Eric Godon is a Belgian actor, best known for his role as Bernard, the eccentric and flamboyant concierge, in the 2007 film "Mr. Bean's Holiday".
Eric Idle is a British comedian, actor, and writer, best known as a member of the Monty Python comedy troupe and for creating the hit musical "Spamalot", which won three Tony Awards in 2005.
Eric Jacobson is an American puppeteer, actor, and writer who is best known for performing and voicing many of the Muppets characters, including Fozzie Bear, Miss Piggy, and Animal, on the ABC television network's The Muppets and Muppets Tonight shows, as well as in various Muppets films and television specials.
Eric Johnson is an American actor, best known for his roles as Kyle Chandler's character's brother, Griffin Holbrook, in the 1993 film "A River Runs Through It" and as Wiley Gatlin in the 1995 film "Unforgiven", for which he received critical acclaim.
Eric Lange is an American actor, best known for his roles as Captain Tom Neville in the NBC television series "Revolution" and as Ryan Shane in the HBO series "Barry".
Eric Lloyd is an American actor, best known for his role as Charlie Calvin, the son of Tim Allen's character Scott Calvin, in the Disney Christmas comedy films "The Santa Clause" (1994) and "The Santa Clause 2" (2002).
Eric Mabius is an American actor, best known for his roles as Daniel Meade in the ABC drama series "Ugly Betty" and as Syphon in the "Resident Evil" film series.
Eric McCormack is a Canadian actor, best known for his starring role as Will Truman in the popular NBC sitcom "Will & Grace" from 1998 to 2006 and its revival from 2017 to 2020.
Eric Mendenhall is a film editor who has worked on several notable movies, including the Oscar-winning film "The Hurt Locker" (2008) and the critically acclaimed film "The Messenger" (2009).
Eric Peterson is a Canadian actor, best known for his long-running role as Jim Walton on the popular sitcom "Corner Gas".
Eric Schweig is a Canadian actor of Cree and German descent, best known for his roles in films such as "Dances with Wolves" (1990), "The New World" (2005), and "The Revenant" (2015), where he played the role of Hikuc, a Native American who helps Leonardo DiCaprio's character, Hugh Glass.
Eric Sheffer Stevens is an American actor, best known for his roles as Reid Braden on the TV series "As the World Turns" and as Dr. Reid on the TV series "The Good Wife".
Eric Stoltz is a renowned American actor, best known for his roles in films such as "Mask", "Pulp Fiction", and "The Butterfly Effect", as well as his brief stint as the original Marty McFly in the "Back to the Future" trilogy before being replaced by Michael J. Fox.
Eric Stonestreet is an American actor, best known for his role as Cameron Tucker, the flamboyant and emotional partner of Mitchell Pritchett, in the ABC sitcom "Modern Family", for which he won two Emmy Awards for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series.
Eric Stuart is an American voice actor, singer, and musician, best known for his roles as Brock in the Pokémon franchise, as well as various other characters in anime and cartoons, such as Donatello in Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and Wally in Pokémon: The Mastermind of Mirage Pokémon.
Eric Winter is an American actor, best known for his roles as Officer Tim Bradford in the TV series "The Rookie" and as Rex Brady on the NBC soap opera "Days of Our Lives".
Erick Avari is a Bangladeshi-American actor, best known for his roles in films such as "Independence Day" (1996), "The Mummy" (1999), and "Planet of the Apes" (2001).
Erick Elias is a Mexican professional wrestler, best known for his time in Asistencia Asesoría y Administración (AAA) and Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide, where he has held multiple championships including the AAA World Cruiserweight Championship and the AAA World Tag Team Championship.
Erik Estrada is a Puerto Rican-American actor and police officer, best known for his starring role as Ponch Poncherello in the popular 1970s-1980s television series "CHiPs".

Erik Palladino is an American actor, best known for his roles as Detective Mike Giardello in the HBO series "The Wire" and as Dr. Dave Malucci in the NBC medical drama "ER".

Erin Boyes is a fictional character from the 2004 American comedy film "Mean Girls", played by actress Lindsay Sloane, who is the best friend of Cady Heron and a member of "The Plastics".
Erin Cipolletti is an American film and television actress, best known for her roles in the TV series "The Fosters" and "Pretty Little Liars".

Vaughan and starring Katja Herbers, Hannah Kasulka, and John Ortiz, which follows a group of people who are part of a secret organization that helps people who have been replaced by identical-looking "Eves" and must uncover the truth behind the mysterious duplicates.

Fred Willard is a renowned American comedic actor, best known for his improvisational skills and memorable roles in films such as "Best in Show", "Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy", and "Waiting...", as well as his numerous appearances on TV shows like "Modern Family" and "Everybody Loves Raymond".

Freddy Rodríguez is a Puerto Rican-American actor, best known for his roles as Gunnery Sergeant Carlos "Pooch" Alvarez in the 2003 film "Stander" and as Eddie Súarez in the TV series "Ugly Betty".
Frederic Forrest is an American actor, best known for his roles in the films "The Rose" (1979), "Apocalypse Now" (1979), and "The Doors" (1991), as well as his long-time collaboration with director Nicolas Cage.
Frederick Weller is an American actor, best known for his roles as Jeff Hafley in the TV series "In Plain Sight" and as Henry Pollard in the TV series "Sneakers".
Fredro Starr is an American rapper, actor, and television personality, best known for his role as Steez in the 1995 film "Bed of Roses" and as a member of the hip-hop group Onyx.
French Stewart is an American actor, best known for his roles as Harry Solomon on the sitcom "3rd Rock from the Sun" and as Dick Campbell on the sitcom "Mom".
Frida Hallgren is a Swedish actress, best known for her roles in films such as "The 13th Warrior" (1994), "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" (2009), and "The Girl Who Played with Fire" (2009), as well as her portrayal of Astrid in the BBC series "Vikings" (2013-2019).
Fritz Kortner was an Austrian-German actor and director who appeared in over 100 films, including the classic German Expressionist films "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari" (1920) and "Waxworks" (1924), and later became a prominent figure in post-war German cinema, directing films such as "The Last Illusion" (1956) and "The Hole" (1959).
Félix Moati is a French actor, screenwriter, and director, best known for his work on films such as "The Trouble with You" and "The French Dispatch", which premiered at the 2021 Cannes Film Festival.

G.W. Bailey is a renowned American actor, best known for his iconic role as Sergeant Otis Pepper in the 1980s comedy film series "Police Academy" and its subsequent sequels.
Gabourey Sidibe is an American actress who gained widespread recognition for her breakout role as Precious Jones in the 2009 film "Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire", for which she received an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress.

I'm Fluffy" and "Hot & Fluffy", as well as his roles in TV shows like "Modern Family" and "Nashville", and films like "The Book of Life" and "Coco".

Greer Garson was a renowned British-American actress who won the Academy Award for Best Actress for her role in the 1942 film "Mrs. Miniver" and was known for her distinctive voice and elegant on-screen presence.
Greg Collins is a fictional character and the main protagonist in the 2002 American psychological thriller film "Paparazzi", played by Cole Hauser, who becomes the target of a group of paparazzi after he kills one of them while trying to protect his family.
Greg Germann is an American actor, best known for his roles as Richard Fish on the TV series "Ally McBeal" and as Dr. Tom Koracick on the ABC medical drama "Grey's Anatomy".
Greg Grunberg is an American actor, best known for his roles as Captain Tom Hansen in the TV series "Alias", as well as his recurring roles as Noah Bennett in the TV series "Heroes" and as Eric Thompson in the TV series "Lost".
Greg Jackson is a renowned American mixed martial arts (MMA) coach and cornerman, known for his work with top fighters such as Jon Jones, Khabib Nurmagomedov, and Charles Oliveira, and is widely regarded as one of the most successful and respected coaches in the sport.
Greg Mottola is a renowned American film and television director, best known for his work on the coming-of-age comedy "Superbad" (2007), the cult classic "Adventureland" (2009), and the hit TV series "Arrested Development" (2003-2006).

Gregory Cruz is an American actor, best known for his role as the young Juan Primo in the 1976 film "The Wilby Conspiracy", starring Michael Caine and Sidney Poitier.
Gregory Itzin is an American actor, best known for his roles as Charles Logan in the TV series "24" and as President John F. Kennedy in the TV movie "Killing Kennedy".

Gregory Smith is a Canadian actor, best known for his roles as Alan Campbell in the TV series "Everwood" and as Detective Stuart Bell in the TV series "Rookie Blue".
Greta Gerwig is a renowned American film director, writer, and actress known for her critically acclaimed works such as "Lady Bird", "Little Women", and "Barbie", which have garnered numerous awards and nominations, including Academy Award nominations for Best Director and Best Adapted Screenplay.
Gretchen Mol is an American actress known for her roles in films such as "Rounders", "Don't Say a Word", and "The Notorious Bettie Page", as well as her portrayal of Ruthie in the HBO series "Boardwalk Empire".

Griffin Kane is a character played by Wesley Snipes in the 1995 film "Money Train", where he is a cop who teams up with his brother to steal a train carrying a large sum of money.
Guang Li is a Chinese film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2004 film "The Missing Gun" and the 2011 film "The Flowers of War", which starred Christian Bale and was nominated for several Academy Awards.
Guillermo Arriaga is a Mexican screenwriter and film director, known for his work on films such as "Amores Perros", "21 Grams", and "Babel", which often explore themes of violence, morality, and the human condition.
Guillermo Francella is an Argentine actor, known for his roles in films such as "XXY" and "The Clan", as well as his work in television, including the popular Argentine series "Sos mi hombre".
Gulshan Grover is a renowned Indian film actor, known for his iconic villainous roles in Bollywood movies such as "Shahenshah", "Khal Nayak", and "Dilwale", and has also appeared in international films like "Dracula: Dead and Loving It" and "The Guru".

Gus Van Sant is a renowned American film director, producer, and screenwriter known for his distinctive filmmaking style and critically acclaimed movies such as "Good Will Hunting", "Elephant", and "Milk", which have garnered numerous awards and nominations, including two Academy Awards.
Gustaf Skarsgård is a Swedish actor known for his roles in films and television shows such as "Vikings", "Westworld", and "The Way Back", as well as his appearances in various Swedish films and dramas.
Gustav Fröhlich was a German actor, best known for his role as Johannes Hinrich Wichmann in the 1927 German silent film "Metropolis", directed by Fritz Lang.

Artificial Intelligence", where he delivered critically acclaimed performances as a young boy who communicates with the dead and a robot boy who is capable of experiencing human emotions.

James Morrison is a 2006 psychological thriller film directed by Steve Tisch, starring Robert Pattinson, James Purefoy, and Christina Ricci, which tells the story of a young man who becomes embroiled in a mysterious and sinister plot after he is released from a mental institution.
James Nesbitt is a Northern Irish actor known for his roles in films such as "Waking Ned Devine", "Bloody Sunday", and "The Hobbit" trilogy, as well as his television work on shows like "Cold Feet" and "The Missing".
James Noble is a British-American actor, best known for his role as Lawrence Tuttle, the stuffy and uptight housemaster, in the TV sitcom "The House on Garibaldi Street" and as the lovable but eccentric President Theodore Roosevelt in the TV series "Buffalo Bill".

James Pickens Jr. is an American actor, best known for his role as Dr. Derek Shepherd's boss, Dr. Richard Webber, on the ABC medical drama television series Grey's Anatomy.

James Robertson Justice was a British actor, best known for his roles in the Doctor series of films, particularly as Dr. Doomsday in "Doctor in the House" (1954), "Doctor at Sea" (1955), and "Doctor at Large" (1957).

James Shigeta was a Japanese-American actor who gained international recognition for his roles in films such as "Flower Drum Song" (1961) and "The Crimson Kimono" (1959), and was one of the first Asian-American actors to achieve mainstream success in Hollywood.
James Tumminia is a film producer and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2003 horror film "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" and its 2006 prequel "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning".

James Wilcox is an American screenwriter and film producer, best known for his work on the 1994 film "The Client" and the 1997 film "L.A. Confidential", both of which were adapted from novels by Thomas Harris and James Ellroy respectively.

Joe Spinell was an American actor, writer, and director, best known for his roles in low-budget horror films, particularly in the 1970s and 1980s, including "Rock 'n' Roll High School" and "Maniac", and was also the writer and star of the cult classic "I Spit on Your Grave".

The Mary Tyler Moore Show is a classic American sitcom that aired from 1970 to 1977, starring Mary Tyler Moore as Mary Richards, a pioneering female television news producer, and featuring a talented ensemble cast, including Ed Asner, Ted Knight, and Valerie Harper, that tackled real-life issues and social commentary with humor and wit.
Mary-Kate Olsen is a former child actress and fashion designer who rose to fame alongside her twin sister Ashley as the dual role of Michelle Tanner on the popular 1990s sitcom "Full House" and later went on to pursue a successful career in fashion, co-founding the luxury fashion brand The Row.

Paulette Goddard was an American actress, fashion model, and Hollywood starlet who was one of the most popular and highest-paid actresses of the 1930s and 1940s, known for her roles in films such as "Modern Times" (1936), "The Great Dictator" (1940), and "So Proudly We Hail!" (1943).

Zheng Xu is a Chinese film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2018 film "The Wasted Times" which premiered at the 75th Venice International Film Festival and won the Best Film award at the 2018 Golden Horse Awards.
Zhengyong Zhang is a Chinese film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2019 film "The Wasted Times" which premiered at the 76th Venice International Film Festival and received critical acclaim for its portrayal of the lives of women in 1930s China.
Zhonghua Chen is a Chinese film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the 2019 film "The Wasted Times" which premiered at the 76th Venice International Film Festival and received critical acclaim for its portrayal of the lives of Chinese women during the Second Sino-Japanese War.
Zinedine Soualem is a French actor, best known for his roles in films such as "The Beat That My Heart Skipped" and "The Witnesses", and has also appeared in numerous French television series and stage productions.
Zoe Kazan is an American actress, playwright, and screenwriter, known for her roles in films such as "Ruby Sparks", "The Big Sick", and "The Ballad of Buster Scruggs", as well as her collaborations with director Paul Dano, with whom she has been in a relationship since 2007.
Zoe Levin is an American actress known for her roles in films such as "The Way Way Back", "The New Normal", and "Scream Queens", as well as her appearances on TV shows like "House M.D." and "Casual".
Zoe Ventoura is an Australian actress, best known for her roles as Dr. Nicole Turner in the Australian television series "Packed to the Rafters" and as Izzy Hoyland in the soap opera "Home and Away".
Zoey Deutch is an American actress known for her roles in films such as "Why Him?", "Before I Fall", "The Year of Spectacular Men", and "Buffaloed", and has also appeared in several TV shows, including "Ringer" and "The Politician".
Zohra Segal was a renowned Indian actress who appeared in numerous Bollywood films, including "Jab We Met" and "Cheeni Kum", and was also a trained dancer and choreographer, having trained under the legendary choreographer Uday Shankar.
Zooey Deschanel is an American actress, singer-songwriter, and model, best known for her roles in the TV shows "New Girl" and "Bones", as well as her quirky and offbeat performances in films like "Elf", "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy", and "Yes Man".
Zoë Bell is a New Zealand-born actress, stuntwoman, and martial artist, best known for her work in films such as Kill Bill, Death Proof, and Hawaii Five-0, and has also appeared in numerous other films and television shows, including Viva, Raze, and Ash vs. Evil Dead.
Zoë Kravitz is an American actress, singer, and model who has appeared in films such as "Big Little Lies", "Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald", and "High Fidelity", and has also been a part of the "X-Men" franchise as the character of Fantomex.
Zoë Poledouris is a Canadian actress and singer, best known for her role as Kira Ford in the TV series "Renegade" and as the daughter of composer Michael W. Smith.
Zubaida Sahar is a Pakistani film actress who appeared in several Lollywood films during the 1950s and 1960s, including the iconic film "Mera Saya" (1969) alongside Waheed Murad.
Zuhair Haddad is a Lebanese film director and screenwriter, best known for his work on the critically acclaimed films "The Night" (1992) and "The Kneading" (1995), which explored themes of identity, culture, and social change in post-civil war Lebanon.
Álex Angulo is a Spanish actor, best known for his role as Julián in the 1995 film "El Alcalde" and as Anselmo in the 1997 film "The Devil's Backbone", both directed by Guillermo del Toro.
Ángela Molina is a Spanish actress who has appeared in numerous films, including Pedro Almodóvar's "What Have I Done to Deserve This?" and "Matador", as well as other notable roles in Spanish cinema.
Émilie Dequenne is a Belgian actress who gained international recognition for her roles in films such as "Rosetta" (1999), "The Girl on the Train" (2003), and "Our Children" (2012), earning her several award nominations and wins, including the Best Actress award at the 1999 Cannes Film Festival.
Óscar Jaenada is a Spanish actor known for his roles in films such as "Life" (2017), "The Shallows" (2016), and "Instructions Not Included" (2013), as well as his work in Spanish television and theater.
